list.title: Question 1
list.content: The Burns, Gordons and Longstaff families make meal plans for their households. The table below shows the amount of carbohydrate, fat and protein, all measured in grams, consumed by the family over a single day. The table also shows the daily calories, measured in kcal, this equates to. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/350ffb2d-5f7c-4d42-9455-67a41e1ff452/images/8ca2d5dd-4221-43ed-b694-8407a3540349/1111a.JPG) Let $x$, $y$ and $z$ represent the amount of calories, in kcal, for $1$ g of carbohydrate, fat and protein respectively. - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $x$, $y$ and $z$ that represents the information in the table above. [2] - Find the values $x$, $y$ and $z$. [2] The Howe family also plans meals. The table below shows the amount of carbohydrates, fat and protein consumed by the family over a single day. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/350ffb2d-5f7c-4d42-9455-67a41e1ff452/images/a0f40aa2-3fd5-4e46-b963-a74843eb2043/1111b.JPG) - Calculate the daily calories for the Howe family. [2]

list.title: Question 2
list.content: The amount of water, $W$, in litres, remaining in a cooking pot after it is placed onto a hot stove is given by the function $$ W(t) = 40(0.75)^t,\quad t\geq 0 $$ where $t$ is the time in hours after the pot is placed on the stove. - Find - the initial amount of water in the pot. - the percentage of water that leaves the pot in the form of steam each hour. [3] - Calculate the amount of water remaining in the pot after $5$ hours. [2]

list.title: Question 3
list.content: An ice cube was dropped into a cup of warm water. The weight of the ice cube, $W$, in grams, reduces as the ice cube dissolves in the water. The weight can be modelled by the following function, $W(t)$, where $t$ is the time in seconds after the dissolving starts. $$ W(t) =28(0.98)^t,\quad t\geq 0 $$ - Find - the initial weight of the ice cube. - the percentage of the ice cube dissolving every $5$ seconds. [3] - Calculate the weight of the ice cube remaining after one minute. [2]

list.title: Question 4
list.content: A toy rocket is fired, from a platform, vertically into the air, its height above the ground after $t$ seconds is given by $s(t) = at^2 + bt + c$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bb0065fc-bc20-4898-a580-9d8d84f4cc81/images/26a3d948-9010-49f6-b623-7aac14c767bf/rocket.png) After $2$ second, the rocket is $28.3$ m above the ground; after $4$ seconds, $25.6$ m; after $5$ seconds, $14.7$ m. - - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3] - Find the height, above the ground, of the platform. [1] - Find the time it takes for the rocket to hit the ground. [2]

list.title: Question 5
list.content: In an ecology experiment, a number of mosquitoes are placed in a container with water and vegetation. The population of mosquitoes, $P$, increases and can be modelled by the function $$ P(t) = 24\times 4^{0.385t}, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0, $$ where $t$ is the time, in days, since the mosquitoes were places in the container. - Find the number of mosquitoes: - initially placed in the container; - in the container after $5$ days. [4] The maximum capacity of the container is $5000$ mosquitoes. - Find the number of days until the container reaches its maximum capacity. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.3em} P(0) &= 24\times 4^{0.385(0)} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 24}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.3em} P(5) &= 24\times 4^{0.385(5)} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 346}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Solving the equation $P(t) = 5000$ for $t$, find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  24\times 4^{0.385t} &= 5000 \hspace{1.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.3em} \answer{t \approx 10.0 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: After $1960$, the economy growth in Australia has grown in an exponential fashion. Australian GDP per capita, $G(t)$, in United States dollars (USD) is modelled by the function $$ G(t) = 1806 \times (1.037)^t, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the number of years since $1960$, and $t \geq 0$. - Write down, in USD, Australian GDP per capita in $1960$. [1] - Find Australian GDP per capita in $1961$. [1] - Find the year for which Australian GDP per capita reaches $100\hspace{0.15em}000$ USD. Give your answer correct to the nearest year. [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{1806 \text{ USD}}$
- Evaluating $G(t)$ for $t = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} G(1) &= 1806 \times (1.037) \\[6pt]
  &= 1872.822 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1870 \text{ USD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $G(t) = 100\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} 1806 \times (1.037)^t &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 110 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence Australian GDP per capita reaches $100\hspace{0.15em}000$ USD
in  $\answer{2070}$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: The sound intensity level, $D$, in decibels (dB), can be modelled by the function $$ D(I) = 10\log_{10}(I) + 120, \hspace{0.5em} I \geq 0, $$ where $I$ is the sound intensity, in watts per square meter (W $/$m$^2$). - A vacuum cleaner has a sound intensity of $1.6\times10^{-5}$ W $/$m$^2$. Calculate the intensity level of the vacuum cleaner. [2] - A fire truck siren has an intensity level of $124$ dB. Find the sound intensity of the siren. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $D(I)$ for $I = 1.6\times10^{-5}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.2em} D\left(1.6\times10^{-5}\right) &= 10\log_{10}\left(1.6\times10^{-5}\right) + 120 \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 72.0 \text{ dB}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(I) = 124$ for $I$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  10\log_{10}(I) + 120 &= 124 \hspace{5.8em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15em} \answer{I \approx 2.51 \text{ W\hspace{-0.1em}$/$m$^2$}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: An eagle is sitting in her nest and scanning the area for prey. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/beb96113-bce6-4e9f-96f9-57c723565e26/eagle.png) The height, $h$, of the eagle above the ground, in metres, is modelled by the following quadratic function. $h(t)=1.8t^2-8.7t+14$, $t \geq 0$ where $t$ is the time in seconds after the eagle begins to move. - Write down the height above the ground of the eagles nest. [1] - The eagle sees a dormouse and swoops down to try and catch it, however, the dormouse runs away and the eagle returns back to the nest. - How high above the ground was the eagle when it turned around and went back to the nest? - How long does it take for the eagle to return to the nest, from the time it left the nest? [4]
list.markScheme:
- The eagle is initially in her nest, that is at $t=0$. Therefore her height is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      h(0)&=1.8\times(0)^2-8.7\times(0)+14\\
      &=14
  \end{align*}
  $$

The nest is $\answer{14\,\text{m}}$ above the ground.
- 
  - The eagle turns around and returns to the nest at the minimum point of $h(t)$ with the $y$-coordinate being the height above the ground at this moment.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/b14f56e1-7645-4a85-a4f1-c17abecdf0c8/para1.png)


    The eagle was $\answer{3.49\,\text{m}}$ above the ground when it turned around.
  - The nest is $14$m above the ground. By solving $h(t)=14$ we can find the time the eagle arrives back at the nest.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/e5dafd1a-8037-4edf-9ab2-63ad77102b02/para2.png)


    The eagle took $\answer{4.83\,\text{s}}$ to return to the nest.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Oliver throws a coin from the open window onto flat horizontal ground in front of his office building. The path of the coin is modelled by the quadratic curve $y = 8 + 3x - 0.5x^2$ , where $x$ represents the horizontal distance the coin is thrown and $y$ represents the height of the coin above the ground. All distances are measured in metres. The wall of the building lies along the $y$-axis. The coin starts its flight at point A, reaches its maximum height at point B, and lands on the ground at point C, as shown on the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/551a9c07-a2a1-4842-bd91-826ca4e267b9/images/be672629-0ece-49eb-b0ba-8f5c76b93870/3194f4c38ebe70fcc80ad86fb61b4fd630cd08ef.svg) - Write down the height in metres from which the coin was thrown. [1] - Calculate the maximum height, above the ground, reached by the coin. [3] - Find the horizontal distance from the base of the wall to the point at which the coin hits the ground. [2]

list.title: Question 10
list.content: In the realm of Artificial Intelligence (AI), machine learning models are trained using data sets. The time taken to train a machine learning model is directly proportional to the size of the training data set. This is shown by the following: $$ \begin{align*} t &\propto x \end{align*} $$ Where $t$ is training time in hours, and $x$ is the size of the training data set in gigabytes. It is known that a certain machine learning model takes $15$ hours to train using a data set of size $100$ gigabytes. - Find an equation for $t$ in terms of $x$. [2] - If a dataset of 250 gigabytes is used, determine the expected training time. [2] The larger the data set that is used for training, the more effective the machine learning model is deemed to be. A new and improved training model has been developed, so that a machine learning model can be trained in the same amount of time as the previous model, using larger data sets. The equation for the new model is $t=0.1x$. - Given a training time of $20$ hours, determine the difference in the size of the data sets between the first and second machine learning models. [3]

list.title: Question 11
list.content: The average daily hours of sunlight, $S$, during a 12-month period in a particular town is given by the function $$ S(t)=a\cos(bt-180)+d, $$ where time, $t$, is measured in months, $a$ and $d$ are constants, and $b$ is measured in degrees. The graph of $S$ versus $t$ is shown in the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8a6e0bdd-88f9-4d71-8c34-6feeedb1d7e0/images/4284ab68-f212-4ca3-8085-e16d1ab13767/aff649079ad71d825a6dc0770f6728fb76b7cce5.svg) - Find the value of - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Write down the values of $t$ when the average daily sunlight is $10$ hours. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    a &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}-S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16-4) \\[6pt]
    % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=6}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}+S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16+4) \\[6pt]
    %   &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(20) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=10}
    \end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $S$ is 12 months. Hence, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &=\dfrac{\ang{360}}{\text{period}} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{\ang{360}}{12} \\[6pt]
  % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
  & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=\ang{30}}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- The graph of $S$ versus $t$ shows that $S(3) =10$ and $S(9) =10$.
Hence, the average daily sunlight hours is 10 for
$\answer{t=3\hspace{0.525em}\text{and}\hspace{0.525em} t=9.}$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: A water tank has a float valve that allows water to enter while the tank is not full. Over time, the float valve reduces the water flow until the tank is almost at its maximum capacity. The amount of water in the tank, in litres, is given by the function $W(t)=5\,000-C\left(1.04^{-t}\right)$ where $t$ is minutes after the tank starts to fill. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b93229be-02cb-4ca6-90cd-091a590021f8/images/206420d5-addd-4321-a0d4-63591b3fa52a/779.JPEG) - Given that the tank was initially empty, find the value of $C$.[2] - State what the horizontal asymptote represents in the context of the question.[1] - Find the total amount of water in the tank after one and half hours. Give your answer in cubic metres. [3]

list.title: Question 13
list.content: A population of $50$ hamsters was introduced to a new town. One month later, the number of hamsters was $62$. The number of hamsters, $P$, can be modelled by the function $$ P(t) = 50\times b^t,\hspace{0.5em} t\geq0, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the time, in months, since the hamsters were introduced to the town. - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Calculate the number of hamsters in the town after $6$ months. [2] A wildlife specialist estimates that the town has enough drink and food to support a maximum population of $2000$ hamsters. - Calculate the number of months it takes for the hamster population to reach this maximum. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Solving the equation $P(1) = 62$ for $b$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times b^1 &= 62 \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
  b &= \dfrac{62}{50} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.4em}\answer{b = 1.24}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 6$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} P(6) &= 50\times(1.24)^6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 182}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 2000$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times(1.24)^t &= 2000 \hspace{3.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.6em} \answer{t \approx 17.1 \text{ months}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 14
list.content: An owl takes off from from a tree branch and flies higher into the sky. Its height above the ground after $t$ seconds, where $t\geq 0$, is given by $s(t) = at^3 + bt^2 + ct+d$, where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f2f10540-8736-484c-b76e-293673a1a920/images/e10ba209-e2d4-4ca9-a89f-fc01ced21fb2/owl.png) Initially the owl is $12\,$ metres above the ground. - Write down the value of $d$. [1] After $1$ second, the owl is $19.8$ m above the ground; after $2$ seconds, $34.5$ m; after $4$ seconds, $22.8$ m. - - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3] After some time the owl reaches a maximum height. At this time it spots some prey at ground level and then immediately swoops down to catch it. - - Find the maximum height of the owl above the ground as it spots the prey. - Find the time it catches the prey. [2]

list.title: Question 15
list.content: The average time, $T$, in seconds, it takes for a customer to find their favourite menu item in an alphabetical menu list can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} T(n) &= \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(n+1), \hspace{0.5em} n \geq 1,\end{aligned} $$ where $n$ is the number of different menu items in the list. Mehmet visits Taste of Adana Restaurant for the first time to have a lunch. - The restaurant serves $10$ different fresh salads. Find the time it takes for Mehmet to find Persian Salad in the Fresh Salads section of the menu list. [2] - It takes $7.5$ seconds for Mehmet to find Lamb Chops Kebab in the Adana Kebab section of the menu list. Find the number of different kebab dishes served by the restaurant. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(n)$ for $n = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} T(10) &= \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(10+1) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.19 \text{ seconds}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(n) = 7.5$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(n+1) &= 7.5 \hspace{6.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.45em} \answer{n = 31} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 16
list.content: The diagram below shows the graph of a quadratic function $f(x) = 2x^2 + bx + c$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f982a52-59ba-4f95-a36a-b780904e0f9b/images/45767584-5045-4282-ac7c-db20e0fb8792/75e0c507b59edc93cc9f79e429c580e90c045817.svg) - Write down the value of $c$. [1] - Find the value of $b$ and write down $f(x)$. [3] - Calculate the coordinates of the vertex of the graph of $f$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{c = -30}$
- The graph of $f$ passes through the point P$(3,0)$.
Hence, using the coordinates of P, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(3) &= 0 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  2(3)^2 + b(3) - 30 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  18 + 3b - 30 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  3b - 12 &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{4em} \answer{b = 4}
  $$

  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.4em} \answer{f(x) = 2x^2 + 4x - 30}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The axis of symmetry of the graph of $f$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em}  x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{4}{2(2)} \\[8pt]
  x &= -1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $f(x)$ for $x = -1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.65em} f(-1) &= 2(-1)^2 + 4(-1) - 30 \\[6pt]
  &= -32\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the vertex are
$\answer{(-1,-32)}$

list.title: Question 17
list.content: PM$2.5$ particles are tiny air pollutants with a diameter of $2.5$ micrometres or less. In comparison, the average diameter of a human hair is about $70$ $\text{micrometres}$. Air pollution from diesel & petrol engines form part of PM$2.5$ emissions and of $\text{particular}$ concern due to the health impacts. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/317d2b94-7c4d-4921-822c-e2e52637e72e/images/6e671114-89e5-4a4e-97fd-f26f87bea003/2e913d65859b2219fd828cae63e39f9922b8ba1c.svg) During a particular working day, the rate of PM$2.5$ emissions, in grams per second, from all road vehicles in Beijing, China is modelled by the function $$ E(t) = 6\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}t - \dfrac{5\pi}{6}\right) + 9, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Find the maximum rate of PM2.5 emissions during the day in Beijing, China.[2] - Find the times at which the maximum rate of PM2.5 emissions occur during the day. [3]
list.markScheme:
- The max value of the sine function is $1$.
Hence the max rate of PM2.5 emissions during the day is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.55em} E_{\text{max}} &= 6(1) + 9 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 15 \text{ g$/$sec}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $E(t) = 15$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} 6\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}t - \dfrac{5\pi}{6}\right) + 9 &= 15 \\[4pt]
  t &= 8,\hspace{0.25em} 20 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the max rate of PM2.5 emissions occurs at
$\answer{8 \text{ am}}$
and  $\answer{8 \text{ pm}}$

list.title: Question 18
list.content: The tip of a large wind turbine's blade rotates at a constant speed on a windy day. Its height, $H$ , in metres, above the ground is modelled by the function $$ H(t) = 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 80, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in seconds, since the turbine was accelerated to its max speed. - Write down the minimum height of the blade's tip above the ground. [2] - Find the height of the blade's tip above the ground after $8$ seconds. [2] - Find the time it takes for the blade's tip to complete one full revolution. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The min value of the sine function is $-1$.
Hence the min height of the blade's tip is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  H_{\text{min}} &= 52(-1) + 80 \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 28\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $H(t)$ for $t = 8$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} H(8) &= 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 8) + 80 \\[6pt]
  &= 52\sin \ang{480} + 80 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 125\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/345633bb-e844-436b-bd39-eff8642672ef/images/5f3d01f7-4c01-4f77-b034-46af9d83cc7a/279de316931380f9a5da6848695c261465d527a8.svg)


  Hence it takes
$\answer{6 \text{ seconds}}$
for the blade's tip to complete one full revolution.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: The orbital velocity, $v$, of a spacecraft in km/s is given by $$ v = -0.0098t + c \ln R, $$ where $t$ is the firing time in seconds, $c$ is the exhaust velocity in km/s and $R$ is the mass ratio. If $R=30$, find - The orbital velocity, $v$, after a firing time of 150 seconds and an exhaust velocity of 3 km/s. [2] - The exhaust velocity, $c$, of the spacecraft traveling at an orbital velocity of $9.5 \text{ km/s}$ after a firing time of 150 seconds. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting in $t=150$, $c=3$ and $R=30$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  v &= -0.0098(150) + (3) \ln (30)\hspace{0.5cm}\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 8.73 \text{ km/s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting in $v=9.5$, $t=150$ and $R=30$, we can solve for $c$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  9.5 &= -0.0098(150) + c \ln (30)\hspace{0.5cm}\\[8pt]
  c \ln (30) &= 9.5 + 0.0098(150)\\[8pt]
  c &= \dfrac{9.5+0.0098(150)}{\ln (30)}\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 3.23 \text{ km/s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 20
list.content: The magnitude of an earthquake, $M$, on the Richter scale, can be modelled by the function $$ M(E) = \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(E) - 3.2, \\[3pt] $$ where $E$ is the amount of energy, in joules, released by the earthquake. - Find the magnitude of an earthquake which releases $6.3\times10^{13}$ joules of $\text{energy}$. [2] The Great Chilean Earthquake of $1960$, the most powerful earthquake recorded in the $20$th century, had a magnitude of $9.5$ on the Richter scale. - Find the amount of energy, in joules, released by the Great Chilean $\text{Earthquake}$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $M(E)$ for $E = 6.3\times10^{13}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} M(E) &= \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(6.3\times10^{13}) - 3.2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 6.00}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $M(E) = 9.5$ for $E$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(E) - 3.2 &= 9.5 \hspace{7.85em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{14.2em} \answer{E \approx 1.12\times10^{19} \text{ joules}} \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 21
list.content: The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a harbour on a particular day can be modelled by the equation $$ D = 2.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/847eec72-676b-4606-a4fb-3dcfedc9b6da/images/4265cedf-520e-4467-bdb0-2d56bcfc7630/19fd3a817fff397619c38bc3f6d8f3794089c50d.svg) - Find the lowest and highest depths of water in the harbour, and the times when they occur. [2] - A large yacht has a draught of $3$ metres. Decide whether the yacht will be able to enter the harbour at $5$ pm. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/847eec72-676b-4606-a4fb-3dcfedc9b6da/images/ba52a231-78e9-46b9-857b-1237e71c6260/99ad31616997cbd93f3b2bcca5b2e21cec1a56b5.svg)


- From the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid above, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D_{\text{min}} = 2.5 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 6, 18} \\[6pt]
  \hspace{4.2em} \answer{D_{\text{max}} = 7.5 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 0, 12, 24}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $D$ when $t = 17$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} D &= 2.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 17) + 5 \\[6pt]
  &= 2.5\cos 5\ang{10} + 5 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 2.83\text{ m} \\[6pt]
  &< 3 \text{ m}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the yacht
$\answer{\text{will not be able}}$
to enter the harbour at $5$ pm.

list.title: Question 22
list.content: For $2019$, the income tax rates for a resident in UK are shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/92f945de-d157-4da3-bd84-e9ceb61ac7f4/images/10766b83-e4d8-4b2c-bca4-d3ffad2296e5/b0ad0a092577a73313e3e5cec3d37079a38fab29.svg) - Write down the highest amount of income that is free of tax. [1] - Calculate the amount of tax payable on the first £$50\hspace{0.15em}000$ of income.[2] - Theresa earns £$148\hspace{0.15em}500$ in $2019$. Find the amount of her income tax payable.[3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{\text{\pounds}12\hspace{0.15em}500}$
- Evaluating tax payable for the income of £$50\hspace{0.15em}000$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1em} \text{Tax payable} &= 0 + 0.2(50\hspace{0.15em}000 - 12\hspace{0.15em}500) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \text{\pounds}7500}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating tax payable for the income of £$148\hspace{0.15em}500$,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \text{Tax payable} &= 7500 + 0.4(148\hspace{0.15em}500 - 50\hspace{0.15em}000) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \text{\pounds}46\hspace{0.15em}900}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 23
list.content: The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a harbour on a particular can be modelled by the equation $$ D = 3\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aa0d706-15a7-45ce-b7c4-c439903d95d0/images/88525833-f18f-4bc6-8659-178e0c8217ce/bc607b763c6a7abff0abf4c7db110b192240d1a3.svg) - Find the lowest and highest depths of water in the harbour, and the times when they occur. [2] - A large boat has a draught of $2.5$ metres. Decide whether the boat will be able to enter the harbour at $8$ pm. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aa0d706-15a7-45ce-b7c4-c439903d95d0/images/c2909ae5-a8e9-4c71-8012-36bfe1b65413/5c4bc36227599f18aecea5fee37d5db9b328bd33.svg)


- From the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid above, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D_{\text{min}} = 2 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 9, 21} \\[6pt]
  \hspace{1.35em} \answer{D_{\text{max}} = 8 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 3, 15}\end{aligned}

- Evaluating $D$ when $t = 20$, we have

$\answer{\text{will not be able}}$
to enter the harbour at $8$ pm.

list.title: Question 24
list.content: The size of the trunk diameter of a chestnut oak tree, $d$, in centimetres, can be modelled by the function $$ d(t) = 9\ln(0.25\hspace{0.05em}t), \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 5, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the age, in years, of the tree. - Find the size of the trunk diameter of a $10$-year-old chestnut oak tree.[2] - The size of the trunk diameter of a chestnut oak tree is $15$ cm. Find its age. [2] A chestnut oak tree can be harvested for wood when the size of its trunk diameter reaches $20$ cm. - Find the age of the chestnut oak tree when it is old enough to be harvested for timber. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $d(t)$ for $t = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d(10) &= 9\ln(0.25(10)) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8.25 \hspace{0.25em}\text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $d(t) = 15$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  9\ln(0.25\hspace{0.05em}t) &= 15 \hspace{7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.1em} \answer{t = 21.2 \text{ years}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $d(t) = 20$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  9\ln(0.25\hspace{0.05em}t) &= 20 \hspace{7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.1em} \answer{t = 36.9 \text{ years}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 25
list.content: Jack, a volleyball player, serves the ball with a trajectory modelled by the function $$ h_1(x)=-0.12x^2+x+0.725 $$ where $h$ is the height of the ball above the ground, in metres, and $x$ is the horizontal distance from the serving point, in metres. - Find the height of the ball when Jack makes his serve (i.e. the height above the ground at the point where he connects with the ball).[2] Unfortunately, the serve is short and misses. For his next attempt, Jack will serve the ball $c$ metres higher at the serving point, so that the ball has the same trajectory (only the vertical height changes, increasing by $c$ metres). - Write down a second function, $h_2(x)$, modelling the new path of the ball in terms of $x$ and $c$.[1] - - Calculate the value of $c$, if the horizontal distance is $10$ metres from the serving point to the point where the ball would hit the ground. - Determine the vertical height of the ball from which Jack makes his successful serve.[4]

list.title: Question 26
list.content: A house located in a town experiencing drought issues features a square-shaped roof, with each side being $x$ meters. The roof is able to catch and store rainwater. During a rainfall, it is known that the mean amount of rainwater ($W$ in litres) collected is directly proportional to the square of $x$. It is known that the system can collect $19\hspace{0.15em}845$ litres when the value of $x$ is $7$ metres. - Find an equation for $W$ in terms of $x$.[2] The formula found in part (a) can be used to determine the mean amount of rainwater ($W$ in litres) collected by other houses in the town with a square roof. - Determine the side length of a square roof that has collected $32\hspace{0.1em}805$ litres during a rainfall. [3]
list.markScheme:
- According to the description we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      W &= cx^2 \\
      19\hspace{0.15em}845 &= c(7)^2 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
      c &= \dfrac{19\hspace{0.15em}845}{49} \\[6pt]
      c &= 405\\[-10pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

Therefore, the formula is $\answer{W(x)=405x^2}$

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$


$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- Substituting $W=32\hspace{0.1em}805$ into our equation from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      32\hspace{0.1em}805 &= 405x^2 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
      x^2 &= \dfrac{32\hspace{0.1em}805}{405} \\[6pt]
      &= 81 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}} \\[6pt]
      &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{x = 9\hspace{0.15em}\text{m}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 27
list.content: Atmospheric pressure, $P$, in kPa, decreases exponentially with increasing height above sea level, $h$. The atmospheric pressure can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} P(h) &= 101\times\bigg(\dfrac{25}{22}\bigg)^{-h},\end{aligned} $$ where $h$ is the height above sea level in kilometres. - Write down the exact atmospheric pressure at sea level, in kPa. [1] Mount Kosciuszko is the highest mountain in Australia with a height of $2228$ $\text{metres}$ above sea level at the top. - Calculate the atmospheric pressure at the top of the Mount Kosciuszko. [2] - Calculate the height where the atmospheric pressure is equal to $10$ kPa. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{101 \text{ kPa}}$
- Evaluating $P(h)$ for $h = 2.228$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.6em} P(2.228) &= 101\times\bigg(\dfrac{25}{22}\bigg)^{-2.228} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 76.0 \text{ kPa}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(h) = 10$ for $h$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  101\times\bigg(\dfrac{25}{22}\bigg)^{-h} &= 10 \hspace{8.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11em} \answer{h = 18.1\hspace{0.25em}\text{km}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 28
list.content: A Ferris wheel rotates at a constant rate in a clockwise direction. The height of a passenger car above the ground, $h$ metres, at time $t$ minutes, can be modelled by $$ \begin{align*} h(t)=a \sin (bt) + c \, , \hspace{3em}\text{where $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$.} \end{align*} $$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/01bb276f-eb90-4d9f-80b8-d3071fb7b4e5/images/a13e08ac-86a9-45d8-9793-3dcecb46fb25/ai1056.PNG) When $t=0$, the passenger car is $75$ metres above the ground. - State the value of $c$.[1] The passenger car first reaches its maximum height of $135$ metres when $t=6$. - Find the value of - $a$. - $b$.[3] A ride on the Ferris wheel consists of two full rotations. - Calculate the how long it takes to ride on the Ferris wheel.[2]

list.title: Question 29
list.content: The graph below shows the amount of money $M$ (in thousands of dollars), in the account of a contractor, where $t$ is the time in months since he opened the account. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/17bf7bc4-74b6-43c8-9455-a3c62c7a5acb/images/be163de5-68b0-49ca-94db-b870708b6869/AI1015a.PNG) - Write down one characteristic of the graph which suggests that a cubic function might be an appropriate model for the amount of money in the account. [1] The equation of the model can be expressed as $M(t)=at^3+bt^2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d \in \mathbb{R}$. It is given that the graph of the model passes through the following points. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/17bf7bc4-74b6-43c8-9455-a3c62c7a5acb/images/5c93f523-f86a-4794-ac51-31c1c41cc134/AI1015b.PNG) - - State the value of $d$. - Using the values in the table, write down three equations in $a$, $b$, and $c$. - By solving the system of equations from part (ii), find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4] If $M$ has a negative value, the contractor is in debt. - Use the model from part (b) to find the number of months the contractor expects to be in debt. Give your answer to the nearest month.
