list.title: Question 30
list.content: The total cost of a gym membership, $C$, in Australian dollars (AUD), in John's Gym can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} C = 65t +30,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the time in months. - Calculate the gym membership cost over a $6$ month duration. [1] - On the grid below, sketch the graph of the function $C = 65t + 30$, for $t\geq0$. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/242b7846-dd0a-4322-956c-9edf06d9bc3f/images/55390a78-3718-4b81-9faf-956a934b2e3f/40ef97be540273524df8765426fe4afbd3aa99f1.svg) - Calculate the time, $t$, in months, when the total cost reach $290$ AUD. [1] In the neighbouring Jetts Gym, the initial payment is $\$75$ higher than in John's Gym, however the monthly fee is $\$35$ lower per month. - Find the number of months it takes for the total cost to be less by attending Jetts Gym in comparison to John's Gym. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $C = 65t + 30$ for $t = 6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.9em} C &= 65(6) + 30 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 420 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $C = 65t + 30$, for $t \geq 0$, on the
grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/242b7846-dd0a-4322-956c-9edf06d9bc3f/images/92290ff7-7fd4-46b2-b43d-07393fff434a/ffcb3caa4ff34c194a63936e0581df79e4c6a499.svg)


- Solving the equation $C = 290$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  65t + 30 &= 290 \hspace{3.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{12.5em} \answer{t = 4 \text{ months}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{John's Gym}:& \hspace{1.0em} C = 65t + 30 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  \text{Jetts Gym}:& \hspace{1.0em} C = 30t + 105 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/242b7846-dd0a-4322-956c-9edf06d9bc3f/images/af2dfaa5-075c-4939-b8c4-fbc3ad83643b/502b76a7a4ee55ede1c0b292e93ff534a6d4ff0f.svg)


  Hence it takes
$\answer{\text{\(2.14\) months}}$
for the total cost to be less by attending Jetts
  Gym in comparison to John's Gym.

list.title: Question 31
list.content: The subscription fee for an online project management software by AB-Tech is $\$ 40$ per month. If the customer buys for a whole year in advance, a discount of $\$130$ is applied. This can be modelled by the following function, $P(n)$, which gives the total cost when paying annually for the subscription. $$ P(n) = 40n - 130,\quad n\geq 12 $$ where $n$ is the number months. - Find the total cost of buying a subscription for $2$ years. [2] - Find $P^{-1}(1790)$. [2] The subscription price for a different online project management tool by YZ-tech is $\$35$ per month, however customers can only purchase annually in advance, and there are no discounts. The total subscription cost of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's software when $n>k$ . - Find the minimum value of $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $n=24$ into the $P(n)$ function, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(n) &=40n-130\\[6pt]
  P(24) &= 40(24)-130 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{=\$ 830}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(n)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $n$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 40n-130 \\[6pt]
  n&=40y-130\\[6pt]
  40y&=n+130\\[6pt]
  y&=\dfrac{n+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  P^{-1}(n) &= \dfrac{n+130}{40}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We can now find
$P^{-1}(1790)$ as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P^{-1}(1790)&=\dfrac{1790+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-3.5em}\answer{P^{-1}(1790)=48 \text{ months}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For AB-tech's software we we were given the pricing function

  $$
  P(n)=40n-130
  
  $$

  For YZ-tech, we can define the function, $S(n)$, to
represent the subscription price for their software

  $$
  S(n)=35n
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2b908e8c-786e-4fec-844c-19b9653ea308/images/7386b1f2-6825-49b7-88df-da2a1e5501e7/7402d7e1fc9d51e4e9f6b0f5ea74f75143d1438e.svg)


  From the graph, $S(n) < P(n)$ for $n>26$.
  The price of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's when $n>26$.
  Therefore,  $\answer{k=26}$

list.title: Question 32
list.content: The Chicago Wheel, the world's first Ferris wheel, was designed and built in 1893 by an American civil engineer, George W. G. Ferris Jr. The height, in metres, above the ground of a passenger on the Chicago Wheel after $t$ minutes can be modelled by the function $h(t) = 38\cos\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{10}(t-10)\Big) + 42$. - Find the maximum height reached by a passenger on the Chicago Wheel. [1] - Find the height above the ground of a passenger $12$ minutes after the ride has started. [1] - Find the time, in minutes, it takes for the Chicago Wheel to complete one $\text{rotation}$. [2] - Given that passengers only complete one rotation on the Chicago Wheel, calculate how long they are more than $65$ metres above the ground. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_{\text{max}} &= 38(1) + 42 \hspace{2.6em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 80 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 12$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} h(12) &= 38\cos\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{10}(12-10)\Big) + 42 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 72.7 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.1em} h_{\text{min}} &= 38\cos(-1) + 42 \\[6pt]
  &= 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation
$h(t) = h_{\text{min}}$ for the smallest $t > 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  38\cos\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{10}(t-10)\Big) + 42 &= 4 \hspace{8.5em}\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15em} \answer{t = 20 \text{ min}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = h(t)$ for $0 \leq t \leq 20$
[$\text{by using G.D.C.}$], we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4717f775-0a3f-4223-b3ee-8b10dddef24b/images/ea76f0bb-2822-4d64-9854-793238d573ca/935019cd90c17f379ec426e2bc01f82901b22530.svg)


  Hence, using the $t$-coordinates of points A and B, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  t_{\text{more than $65$\hspace{0.25em}m}} &= 12.9 -  7.07 \hspace{2.3em}  \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.86 \text{ min}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 33
list.content: Jasper owns a business and has 7 employees. He can assign any number of employees to a task. The time the task takes varies inversely with the number of employees who are assigned to it. This is shown by the following: $$ \begin{align*} t &\propto \dfrac{1}{x} \end{align*} $$ Where $t$ is time a task takes in hours, and $x$ is the number of employees assigned to the task. If one employee is assigned to a task, it will take 8 hours to complete the task. - Find an equation for $t$ in terms of $x$. [2] Jasper has a task that must be completed within three hours. - - Determine the minimum number of employees that should be assigned to the task to ensure it is completed within three hours. - State the total amount of time the task will take. Give your answer to the nearest minute. [3] If a task does not take a whole number of hours, Jasper must round up to the nearest whole hour to pay his employees. - Determine the optimal number of employees Jasper should assign to ensure the task is complete within three hours, while minimising the number of hours of work he needs to pay for. [3]

list.title: Question 34
list.content: Tom has a model train set, which includes a tunnel that the model train must pass through. The entrance of the tunnel is in the shape of the parabola $h(x)=-0.6x^2+3.12x$, where $h$ is the height of the tunnel in centimetres, and $x$ is the horizontal distance from the bottom left corner of the tunnel entrance at $(0,0)$, also in centimetres. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b56be12-9b7e-47a6-8d33-db4ce1696bee/images/987cf5eb-a4ea-4400-b222-435b2427a3c5/AI1017a.PNG) - Find the equation of the axis of symmetry of the parabola that models the tunnel entrance. [2] Tom is considering purchasing a new carriage for his model train. The carriage is in the shape of a cuboid with a height of $3.5\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}$ and a width of $2\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}$. - Determine whether the carriage will fit through the tunnel entrance. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the formula for the axis of symmetry of a quadratic function, with $a=-0.6$ and $b=3.12$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= - \dfrac{b}{2a} \\[11pt]
  &= - \dfrac{3.12}{(2)(-0.6)} \\[11pt]
  & \hspace{-0.55em}\tcbhighmath{x = 2.6}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Since the height of the carriage is $3.5\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}$ we can find the available horizontal width by finding the intersection of the parabola with the line $y=3.5$. Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b56be12-9b7e-47a6-8d33-db4ce1696bee/images/0c8e24b3-697a-4ff7-9ac8-0f36449f9dc2/AI1017b.PNG)


  Since the length of segment AB is $3.563-1.637=1.926$, and $1.926<2$, we conclude that $\answer{\text{the carriage will not be able to fit through the tunnel entrance.}}$

list.title: Question 35
list.content: The cross-section of a ship's hull below the surface of the ocean can be modelled by a parabola. The depth of the boat's hull, $d$ metres, is given by $d(x) = 0.5x^2-6.4x$, where $x$ is the horizontal distance from the left-hand side of the hull at the surface, also in metres, as shown in the following diagram. The $x$-axis represents the ocean surface. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50b7a549-0fae-4e88-8198-43d4e8b67c4a/images/cb400f16-0845-431b-94dc-26dd2eb56467/AI1018a.PNG) - Find the equation of the axis of symmetry of the parabola that models the hull of the ship. [2] The ship has a horizontal storage deck at a depth of $10$ metres, with a ceiling at surface level. The storage deck is used to transport containers in the shape of cuboids. - Determine the maximum width of a container that the ship can transport on the storage deck, given that the container is $10$ metres high. Give your answer to the nearest metre. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the formula for the axis of symmetry of a quadratic function, with $a=0.5$ and $b=-6.4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= - \dfrac{b}{2a} \\[11pt]
  &= - \dfrac{-6.4}{(2)(0.5)} \\[11pt]
  & \hspace{-0.55em}\tcbhighmath{x = 6.4}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Since the depth of the storage deck is $10\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}$, we can find the available horizontal width by finding the intersection of the parabola with the line $y=-10$. Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50b7a549-0fae-4e88-8198-43d4e8b67c4a/images/0c8115e4-bb78-4db4-b0b4-d73febbc287e/AI1018b.PNG)


  Since the length of segment AB is $10.98 - 1.822 = 9.158$ we conclude:
  The maximum width of a transportable container that is $10$ metres high is $9$ metres.

list.title: Question 36
list.content: The total cost of a ride, $C$, in British pounds (GBP), on BlackCabs can be $\text{modelled}$ by the function $$ C = 1.75x + 3.00, \\[3pt] $$ where $x$ is the distance travelled in kilometres. - Calculate the total cost of an $8$ kilometre ride in a BlackCab. [1] - On the grid below, sketch the graph of the function $\text{\(C\hspace{-0.1em}=\hspace{-0.1em}1.75x + 3.00\)}$, for $\text{\(x\hspace{-0.1em}\geq\hspace{-0.1em}0\)}$.[2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6340868f-a8d3-4dff-a066-c93ed0c4bad4/images/813cd0c4-bfc6-4212-aaf2-af18bdc2015e/c07ee70da58c7beac03974a72c1af86381c22994.svg) - Calculate the distance travelled, $x$, in kilometres, when the total cost of a ride reach $45$ GBP. [1] The starting fare of MiniCabs is $2.00$ GBP higher than of BlackCabs, however the ride fare is lower at $1.40$ GBP per kilometre travelled. - Find the least number of whole kilometres required to travel for the total cost to be less on a MiniCab ride in comparison to a BlackCab ride. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $C = 1.75x + 3.00$ for $x = 8$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} C &= 1.75(8) + 3.00 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 17 \text{ GBP}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph
of $\text{\(C\hspace{-0.15em}=\hspace{-0.15em}1.75x\hspace{-0.15em}+\hspace{-0.15em}3.00\)}$, for $\text{\(x\hspace{-0.15em}\geq\hspace{-0.15em}0\)}$, on the grid $\text{below}$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6340868f-a8d3-4dff-a066-c93ed0c4bad4/images/b628cbad-3d33-4732-a1c3-7206661a40ba/0fbc572f5386caf92a0b3a37fe873d0c550a8cee.svg)


- Solving the equation $C = 45$ for $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1.75x + 3.00 &= 45 \hspace{6.95em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.2em} \answer{x = 24 \text{ km}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{BlackCab}:& \hspace{1.0em} C = 1.75x + 3.00 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  \text{MiniCab}:& \hspace{1.0em} C = 1.40x + 5.00 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $x \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6340868f-a8d3-4dff-a066-c93ed0c4bad4/images/48426bc3-2d7a-45b4-bfc3-9e0988433f8c/e7c289a4de8f1b0042a6607943738c5b0d6aeabd.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(6\) km}}$
is required to travel for the total cost of the ride to be
  less on a MiniCab than on a BlackCab.

list.title: Question 37
list.content: The Mohs scale of mineral hardness is a qualitative, discrete scale characterizing the scratch resistance of various minerals through the ability of harder materials to scratch softer ones. It ranges from talc (1), the softest mineral, to diamond (10), the hardest. Minerals are assigned a whole number value on the Mohs scale. Absolute hardness of a mineral quantifies its resistance to scratching on a continuous scale, providing a more precise measurement than the Mohs scale. The relationship between Mohs scale score, $M$, and absolute hardness, $H$, is given by $$ \begin{align*} 0.319M &= \log_{10}H-0.117 \end{align*} $$ - Calculate the Mohs scale score for quartz, which has an absolute hardness of 100. Give your answer to the nearest whole number. [2] - Find $H$ as a function of $M$.[2] - Calculate the absolute hardness of fluorite, which has a Mohs scale score of 4.[2] - Hence determine how many times greater the absolute hardness of quartz is than the absolute hardness of fluorite.[2]

list.title: Question 38
list.content: Two identical water waves pass a sensor in an oceanography laboratory. As the waves pass the sensor, the depth, $D$, in metres, of water is recorded and modelled by the function $$ D(t) = 3.21-0.45\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{24.2}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in seconds, since the first wave hit the sensor. - Find the minimum and maximum depths of the water as the two waves pass the sensor. [3] - Find the first time after $16$ seconds at which the depth of water reaches $\text{\(3.5\)\hspace{0.25em}m}$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max depths of water are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D_{\text{min}} &= 3.21-0.45(+1) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2.76 \text{ m}} \\[15pt]
  \hspace{1em} D_{\text{max}} &= 3.21-0.45(-1) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3.66 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(t) = 3.5$ for first $t > 16$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3.21-0.45\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{24.2}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) &= 3.5 \hspace{13em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{8.6em} \answer{t \approx 20.3} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 39
list.content: Coral is a wildlife expert who tags flying fish and records their movement using an electronic device. The tagging device tells her the height of a fish relative to the water level, at any given time. She knows that the fish swim mostly in the water, but occasionally they fly (jump!) out of the water. The height is measured in metres and the time in seconds. If the height is negative the fish is under the water, if the height is positive the fish is flying. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/99db50ab-81ea-421b-8f20-21b4669fedcd/images/70f02a92-7870-456a-abea-c262c3ce2d2b/seagull.png) Coral notices one particular fish as it flies out of the water. The moment it re-enters the water the device begins tracking its height. At $2$ seconds the fish is at a height of $-2.8\,$m; at $5$ seconds the fish is at a height of $-2\,$m and at $11$ seconds the fish is also at a height of $-2\,$m. The height of the fish can be expressed as $H(t)=at^3+bt^2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d \in \mathbb{R}$. - - Write down the value of $d$. - Using the information given write down three equations involving $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Solve the system of equations to find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4] From previous research, Coral knows that if a fish is flying for more than $1$ second then a seagull will attempt to catch it. - Use a justification to explain why a seagull will attempt to catch this fish. [4] At $t=9\,$s a seagull begins swooping down to catch the fish. Its height is given by $b(t)=-1.5t^2+27t-118$. - - Find the height at which the bird catches the fish. - Interpret the answer in the context of the problem. [4]

list.title: Question 40
list.content: A team of painters is hired to paint a house. The time $T$ (in hours) required to paint the house varies inversely with the number of painters, $P$. This can be expressed as $$ \begin{align*} T &= \dfrac{k}{P} \end{align*} $$ A team of 3 painters can paint the house in 12 hours. - Write an equation relating the time $T$ to the number of painters $P$.[2] The following diagram shows the graph of $T=P$ for $0 \leq P \leq 12$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f6c0dfc-56fd-41ec-9a8d-73c9b11fe61f/images/5820e2f4-959d-4183-85b4-14415d66fc32/AI1177a.JPG) - On the axes above, sketch the graph of $T(P)$ for $3 \leq P \leq 12$.[2] - State the coordinates of the point of intersection.[1] - State the meaning of the coordinates of this point in the context of the question. [1]

list.title: Question 41
list.content: Consider the quadratic function $f(x) = ax^2+bx+c$. The graph of $y=f(x)$ is shown in the diagram below. The vertex of the graph has coordinates $\text{R}(m,-9)$. The graph intersects the $x$-axis at two points; $\text{P}(-4,0)$ and $\text{Q}(2,0)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b09e52c7-02f5-45a2-96f9-ab7aa4138a3b/images/a78c2481-ec6d-41fe-99c5-6ab402d1c48c/b188999a18650c4961f7def85ea1bfd8a1276fc9.svg) - Find the value of $m$. [1] - Find the values of $a$, $b$, and $c$.[5] - Write down the equation of the axis of symmetry of the graph. [1]

list.title: Question 42
list.content: Certain content on the internet can become viral when the content spreads exponentially. The spread of content published by a specific content creator can be modelled by the function $$ N(t)=145 \times 1.25^t, $$ where $N$ is the number of people reached by the content, and $t$ is the number of hours since the content's publication. - Write down the number of people reached immediately after the content's publication.[1] - Calculate the number of hours it takes for the content to reach $100\hspace{0.15em}000$ people.[2] - Calculate the number of people reached after $80$ hours.[2] Approximately $5$ billion people in the world are now connected to the internet. - Explain why the model starts to become unrealistic after about $3$ days.[1]
list.markScheme:
- The immediate number of people reached can be found when $t=0$.
Hence,

  $$
  \answer{N(0)=145}
  $$

- We solve the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(t) &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[4pt]
  145 \times 1.25^t &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[4pt]
  t &\answer{t\approx29.3}\hspace{3em} [\text{using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting $t=80$ into the function $N(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(t) &= 145 \times 1.25^t \\[4pt]
  N(80) &= 145 \times 1.25^{80} \\[4pt]
  &= 8\hspace{0.15em}206\hspace{0.15em}709\hspace{0.15em}165.19 \\[4pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx8\hspace{0.15em}210\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.15em}000}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{The model becomes unrealistic after about 3 days (72 hours) as the output of the model}}$
  $\answer{\text{(number of people reached) starts to exceed the total number of people in the world }}$
  $\answer{\text{connected to the internet.}}$

list.title: Question 43
list.content: The most popular mobile phone plans in $2019$ from a major mobile service provider in Australia are summarised in the table below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b75a904d-f2de-4d46-bdc6-b410cc688853/images/6cf3428b-91b5-413a-90f3-ffc1bf9e7a1b/4b6cfffce9db227a1223cd6215b239f9cf62d983.svg) - The total monthly cost, $C$, in AUD, of the Optimal Data Plan can be $\text{modelled}$ as a piecewise linear function of the amount of data, $d$, in GB, used. Determine the model. [4] - Find down the total monthly cost of the Optimal Data Plan if: - $8$ GB of data is used; - $12$ GB of data is used. [3] - Determine how many GB of data is used when the Optimal Data Plan $\text{becomes}$ more expensive than the Massive Data Plan. [2] Daniela is using the Optimal Data Plan and is thinking of changing it to the $\text{Massive}$ Data Plan. It is the evening of December $7$, $2019$ and she has already used $3.5$ GB of data so far. Assume that her data usage continues at the same constant rate during December and the next year. - Estimate Daniela's data usage in December. [2] - Hence explain why Daniela should change her plan. [1] - Find the amount of money Daniela will save each month in $2020$ if she changes her Optimal Data Plan to the Massive Data Plan.[2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{C(d) = \left\{ \begin{array}{lcl}
  39, && 0\leq d \leq 10 \\[6pt]
  39 + 10(d-10), && d > 10 
  \end{array} \right.}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{39 \text{ AUD}}$
  - Evaluating $C(d)$ for $d = 12$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} C(12) &= 39 + 10(12-10) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 59 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Solving the equation $C(d) = 79$ for $d > 10$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.6em} 39 + 10(d-10) &= 79 \\[6pt] 
  d &= 14 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
Optimal Data Plan becomes more expensive than Massive Data Plan
  $\answer{\text{when more than \(14\) GB of data is used}}$
- Daniela's approximate data usage in December is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{3.5}{7} \times 31 &= \hspace{0.525em}\answer{15.5 \text{ GB}} \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{Because her current plan is more expensive than Massive Data Plan}}$
- Evaluating $C(d) - 79$ for $d = 15.5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  C(15.5) - 79 &= [39 + 10(15.5-10)] - 79\\[6pt]
  &= 94 - 79 \\[6pt] 
  &\answer{= 15 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 44
list.content: The graph below shows the profit $P$ (in thousands of dollars), that business A makes, where $t$ is the time in months since January 1st. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/c66ce31d-cb54-4bbd-848a-ef2cd4a05037/ai1106e.PNG) - Write down one characteristic of the graph which suggests that a cubic function might be an appropriate model for the business profit. [1] The model can be expressed as $P(t)=at^3+bt^2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d \in \mathbb{R}$. It is given that the graph of the model passes through the following points. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/ef93a216-cfb9-450f-a315-71dbbb9af371/ai1106b.PNG) - - State the value of $d$. - Using the values in the table, write down three equations in $a$, $b$, and $c$. - By solving the system of equations from part (ii), find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4] If $P$ has a negative value, business A is losing money. The owner has decided they will not open during the corresponding time next year. - Use the model from part (b) to find the approximate dates during which business A will not open next year. [4] Business B has a profit function given by $P(t)=-0.1t^2+1.2t$, for $0 \leq t \leq 12$. - Determine the total amount of time for which business B is more profitable than business A. [3]

list.title: Question 45
list.content: The amount of fuel in a car's tank, $V$, in litres, can be modelled by a linear function, $V = mx + c$, where $x$ is the distance driven measured in kilometres. After driving $100$ km, the amount of fuel in the tank is $33$ litres. - Write down an equation that describes this information. [1] After driving $250$ km, the amount of fuel in the tank is $22.5$ litres. - Write down an equation that describes this second piece of information. [1] - Calculate the amount of fuel in the tank after driving $50$ km. [4]

list.title: Question 46
list.content: The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a boating marina on a particular day can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} D(t) &= 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Write down the depth of water at midnight. [1] - The cycle of water depths repeats every T hours. Find the value of T. [2] - - Write down the minimum and maximum depths of water during the day. - Find the times at which the minimum and maximum depths of water occur during the day.[4] - Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below.[3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13a225e5-63c6-476e-81ff-2ded39715f6e/images/9f9c68ce-1d0d-4487-a7d2-c9a33bc05e53/65ae508d3aaa92f2c9dd08b381c4298f16693fe9.svg) - A ship with $8$ m draught is allowed to enter the marina if the depth of water is greater than $10$ m. Find the time interval before midday, in hours and minutes, during which the ship is not allowed to enter the marina. [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{12.5\text{ m}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{T} &= \dfrac{360}{30} \hspace{0.1em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{=12}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The min and max values of the sine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max depths of water are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    D_{\text{min}} &=  4(-1)+12.5 \hspace{0.2em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 8.5\text{ m}} \\[15pt]
    D_{\text{max}} &=  4(+1)+12.5 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 16.5\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $D(t) = 8.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.9em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 8.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 9,\hspace{0.25em} 21 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the min depth of water occurs at
$\answer{9 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{9 \text{ pm}}$
    Similarly, solving the equation $D(t) = 16.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.8em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 16.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 3,\hspace{0.25em} 15 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the max depth of water occurs at
$\answer{3 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{3 \text{ pm}}$

- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13a225e5-63c6-476e-81ff-2ded39715f6e/images/3fbc1ff1-c2d9-4c80-a98e-ea0dfbdfbd10/51784b29690fe6ba6b16afe9863a1352814ae7c6.svg)


- Solving the equation $D(t) = 10$ for $t < 12$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.8em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 10 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 7.289,\hspace{0.25em} 10.711 \hspace{2.8em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.289(60) &= 17.34 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  0.711(60) &= 42.66\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the ship is not allowed to
enter the marina
$\answer{\text{between 7:17 am and 10:43 am}}$

list.title: Question 47
list.content: The number of French words, $N$, that are remembered by students after the completion of a French language course decreases exponentially over time. This data can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} N(t) = a\times b^{-t} + 450,\end{aligned} $$ where $a$ and $b$ are positive constants, and $t$ is the time in years since a student completed the French language course. Immediately after completion, a student remembers $4200$ French words. - Find the value of $a$. [2] After $4$ years a student remembers only $1600$ French words. - Find the value of $b$. [3] The number of French words a student remembers never decreases below a certain number of words, $n$. - Write down the value of $n$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Solving the equation $N(0) = 4200$ for $a > 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\times b^{-0} + 450 &= 4200 \hspace{5.4em} \\[6pt]
  a + 450 &= 4200 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{a = 3750}
  $$

- Solving the equation $N(4) = 1600$ for $b > 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3750\times b^{-4} + 450 &= 1600 \hspace{6.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.6em} \answer{b \approx 1.34} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = N(t)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1aa30751-ed4b-44ac-bb07-63116dc7d37f/images/2a235dae-dec6-4e18-9719-39fb24c0f276/5f0266262d56defec1ffa52f191a9228b568fd3e.svg)


  Hence the value of $n$ is
$\answer{450}$

list.title: Question 48
list.content: Mehmet organises a graduation party on a boat in the Strait of Istanbul for his peers from college. The cost to rent a large boat for the evening is $5000$ Turkish liras (TRY) and the cost to hire a DJ is $1500$ TRY. The cost for food and drinks is estimated to be $125$ TRY per person. - Find an expression for the total cost, $y$ TRY, of the evening in terms of the number of peers, $x$, attending the party. [2] - Find the total cost of the evening if $40$ peers attend the party. [2] - Given that Mehmet decides to collect $250$ TRY from each peer attending the party, find the least number of peers he has to invite to be able to cover the total cost of the evening. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} \text{Total cost} &= \text{Fixed costs} +  \text{Variable costs} \\[6pt]
  y &= (5000+1500) + 125x \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = 6500 + 125x} \hspace{1.2em}
  $$

- Evaluating $y = 6500 + 125x$ for $x = 40$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 6500 + 125(40) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 11\hspace{0.15em}500 \text{ TRY}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Total cost} &= 250x \hspace{9.2em} \\[6pt]
  6500 + 125x &= 250x \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{5.1em} \answer{x = 52} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 49
list.content: The bench press world record weight, $W$, in kilograms, is modelled by the function $$ W(t) = \dfrac{M}{1 + Ce^{-0.04t}}, $$ where $t$ is the number of years that have passed since $1953$. The first bench press world record of $227.27$ kg was set in $1953$. According to bench press experts, the record weight will eventually reach a limit of $350$ kg. - - Write down the value of $M$. - Find the value of $C$ , giving your answer correct to $2$ decimal places. [3] - The current unbeaten bench press world record weight is $337$ kg. Find the year in which this record was set. [2] - A young and promising powerlifter claims that he is going to break any bench press world record performed until $2025$. Find the weight that he has to bench press in $2025$ to set a new bench press world record according to the model. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{M = 350}$
  - Solving the equation $W(0) = 227.27$ for $C$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{350}{1 + Ce^{-0.04(0)}} &= 227.27 \hspace{5.6em} \\[6pt]
    \dfrac{350}{1 + C} &= 227.27 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{9.6em} \answer{C \approx 0.54} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
    $$


- Solving the equation $W(t) = 337$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.9em} \dfrac{350}{1 + 0.54e^{-0.04t}} &= 337 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 66 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/515632bd-ef04-40ae-b5cf-41c585276775/images/17a3be18-8a25-4d9c-9902-4ab75a6551e2/3995fc167568b86787ae79ed98ca134320f14178.svg)


  Hence the current unbeaten bench press world record was set in
$\answer{2019}$
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/515632bd-ef04-40ae-b5cf-41c585276775/images/592efbef-223b-4918-a7ee-77220e95126c/00dae124260e7339716684c3dd5812e8ff1deace.svg)


  Hence, evaluating $W(t)$ for $t = 72$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.7em} W(72) &= \dfrac{350}{1 + 0.54e^{-0.04(72)}} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 340 \text{ kg}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 50
list.content: The water depth, $D$, in metres, at the entrance of a boating harbour can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} D(t) &= 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Write down the depth of water at midnight. [1] - The cycle of water depths repeats every T hours. Find the value of T. [2] - - Write down the minimum and maximum depths of water during the day. - Find the times at which the minimum and maximum depths of water occur during the day.[4] - Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below.[3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5eb2e8d5-7054-4bdd-9c01-bd9a1fa5f2b9/images/2593030c-67cf-409b-9794-ba745de824ef/5ebec9fd250b988a5cdb00654083b4ecdda5ad72.svg) - A ship with $10$ m draught is allowed to enter the harbour if the depth of $\text{water}$ is greater than $12$ m. Find the time interval after midday, in hours and minutes, during which the ship is not allowed to enter the harbour. [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{15\text{ m}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{T} &= \dfrac{360}{30} \hspace{0.1em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{=12}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max depths of water are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    D_{\text{min}} &=  4.5(-1)+15 \hspace{0.2em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 10.5\text{ m}} \\[15pt]
    D_{\text{max}} &=  4.5(+1)+15 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 19.5\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $D(t) = 10.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15 &= 10.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 3,\hspace{0.25em} 15 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the min depth of water occurs at
$\answer{3 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{3 \text{ pm}}$
    Similarly, solving the equation $D(t) = 19.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.1em} 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15 &= 19.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 9,\hspace{0.25em} 21 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the max depth of water occurs at
$\answer{9 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{9 \text{ pm}}$

- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5eb2e8d5-7054-4bdd-9c01-bd9a1fa5f2b9/images/26c8f477-b4fc-4200-831b-ec38467e5a08/86eb70569effce9a800c12036b0b3ecc63fb97b4.svg)


- Solving the equation $D(t) = 12$ for $t > 12$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.1em} 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15 &= 12 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 13.394,\hspace{0.25em} 16.606 \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.394(60) &= 23.64 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  0.606(60) &= 36.36\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the ship is not allowed to

  enter the harbour
$\answer{\text{b\(/\)n 1:24 pm and 4:36 pm}}$

list.title: Question 51
list.content: Two carpet cleaning companies have different pricing structures. CarpetShine charges $1.80$ AUD per square metre, plus an upfront scheduling fee of $50$ AUD. CleanMaster has no scheduling a service fee, but the rate is $2.50$ AUD per square metre. Let $C_1(x)$ and $C_2(x)$ be the costs, in AUD, of cleaning $x$ square metres of carpet area by CarpetShine and CleanMaster respectively. - Write down expressions for the costs, $C_1$ and $C_2$, of cleaning $x$ square metres of carpet area. [2] - Find the least number of whole square metres of carpet area cleaned by $\text{CarpetShine}$ for its $\text{services}$ to be a cheaper option. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{CarpetShine}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_1(x) = 1.80x + 50} \hspace{0.6em} \qref{(1)}  \\[8pt]
  \text{CleanMaster}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_2(x) = 2.50x} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $x \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5fc2ff98-42dc-416f-a3a0-c7e1d46e3145/images/51d828e3-1f65-46c3-8c32-7a9992ed51a6/222304bb048f5e481f5e9f67da7635f92b5b303e.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(72\) whole square metres}}$
of carpet area is required for
  CarpetShine's cleaning services to be a cheaper option.

list.title: Question 52
list.content: The mass of a radioactive sample is given by $$ M(t)=P+Q\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^\frac{t}{300}, \qquad t\geq 0 \text{ days.} $$ where t is the number of days after the sample was collected and measured. The initial weight of the sample is $20 \text{ g}$. When each atom emits its $\alpha$-particle, the mass of the atom is reduced by $3.2\%$. - - Explain why P is the final mass of the sample after every atom in the sample has emitted its $\alpha$-particle. - Hence, find the value of P, leaving your answer correct to two decimal places. [2] - Find the value of Q. [2] - Estimate the mass of the sample after $2.5$ years (assume no leap years). [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    M(t)=P+Q\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^\frac{t}{300}
    $$

    $\answer{{\text{As } t\rightarrow \infty, \left(\dfrac{1}{2} \right)^\frac{t}{300} \rightarrow 0. \text{ Therefore }, M(\infty) \approx P.}}$
  - Hence

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2cm}P &= 0.968\times 20 \qquad [\text{$96.8\%$ of $20$}]\\[6pt]
    &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 19.36 \text{ g}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- We have $M(0)=20$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  M(0) &= P+Q\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^0\\[6pt]
  20 &= 19.36+Q\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-0.25cm}\answer{ Q = 0.64 }\end{aligned}
  $$

- $2.5$ years is $2.5\times 365 = 912.5 \text{ days}$. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  M(912.5) &= 19.36+0.64\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{912.5}{300}}\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{\approx 19.4  \text{ g}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 53
list.content: An oil tank at a mine site was at full capacity before the tank incurred a puncture in the base and the oil start to leak out. A site engineer used the following function, $L(t)$, to model the percentage of oil remaining in the tank $$ L(t)=100e^{-kt},\quad t\geq0, $$ where $t$ is the number of days after the puncture occurred. The engineer found that after one day, $30\%$ of the oil originally in the tank had leaked out. - Find the value of $k$. [2] - Use this model to find the percentage of oil remaining in the tank after $30$ hours. [2] Based on the model, the engineer makes the claim that the tank will always have some oil in it and never completely empty. - State a mathematical reason supporting the engineers claim. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If $30\%$ oil has leaked, there is $70\%$ remaining in the tank. We
can substitute in $L=70$ and $t=1$ to find $k$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L(t) &=100e^{-kt}\\[6pt]
  70 &=100e^{-k(1)}  \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.3em}\answer{\text{k}\approx0.357}  \hspace{2em} [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- $30$ hours is equal to $1.25$ days ($30/24=1.25$). Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L(1.25) &= 100e^{-0.357(1.25)} \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{=64 \%}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- We have $L(t)=100e^{-0.357t}$
  As $t\rightarrow \infty,\,\, L(t)\rightarrow 0$. Hence, there is a horizontal asymptote at $L=0$. The percentage of oil remaining gets very close to zero, but never reaches it.

list.title: Question 54
list.content: An elephant raised in a wildlife sanctuary. Her height, $H$, in metres, is modelled by the logistic function $$ \begin{aligned} H(t) &= \dfrac{2.5}{1+1.5e^{-0.25t}}\hspace{0.05em},\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the number of years that have passed since her birth. - Find the elephant's height: - when she was born; - on her $5$th birthday. [4] The elephant's height approaches a limit of $M$ metres as she ages. - Write down the value of $M$. [1] The elephant reaches a height of $2$ m before her $n$th birthday. - Find the smallest value of $n$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Evaluating $H(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} H(0) &= \dfrac{2.5}{1+1.5e^{-0.25(0)}} \\[9pt]
    &\answer{= 1 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $H(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} H(5) &= \dfrac{2.5}{1+1.5e^{-0.25(5)}} \\[9pt]
    &\answer{\approx 1.75 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- $\answer{M = 2.5}$
- Solving the equation $H(t) = 2$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.1em} \dfrac{2.5}{1+1.5e^{-0.25t}} &= 2 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 7.17 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{n = 8}$

list.title: Question 55
list.content: Two IT consulting firms have different pricing structures. TechMind charges $\$115$ per hour, plus an upfront fee of $\$250$ for booking an appointment. RiddleBreak doesn't charge for booking an appointment, but the rate is $\$160$ per hour. Let $C_1(t)$ and $C_2(t)$ be the costs, in dollars, of consulting $t$ hours by TechMind and RiddleBreak respectively. - Write down expressions for the costs of consulting, $C_1$ and $C_2$, in terms of the number of hours, $t$, charged. [2] - Find the least number of whole hours of consulting from TechMind for its $\text{services}$ to be a cheaper option. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{TechMind}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_1(t) = 115t + 250} \hspace{0.6em} \qref{(1)}  \\[8pt]
  \text{RiddleBreak}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_2(t) = 160t} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9ff19c56-9082-4058-a2cf-c84b25aad999/images/a990f43d-8499-4644-b38a-ba9bd26a4dc4/798f80d7abe42cc91e804962407e19461e89e38d.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(6\) whole hours}}$
is required for TechMind's consulting services
  to be a cheaper option.

list.title: Question 56
list.content: A cannon-ball is fired from the top of a tower. The height, $h$, in metres, of the cannon-ball above the ground is modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} h(t) = -2t^2 + 20t + 8, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the time, in seconds, since the moment the cannon-ball was fired. - Write down the height of the tower. [1] - Calculate the height of the cannon-ball $5$ seconds after it was fired. [2] The cannon-ball hits its target on the ground $n$ seconds after it was fired. - Find the value of $n$. [2] - Find $h'(t)$. [2] - Calculate the maximum height reached by the cannon-ball, and write down the corresponding time $t$. [3] - Determine the total time the cannon ball was above the height of the tower.[3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} h(0) &= -2(0)^2+20(0)+8 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} h(5) &= -2(5)^2+20(5)+8 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 58 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $h(n) = 0$ for $n > 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2n^2+20n+8 &= 0 \hspace{9em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.2em} \answer{n \approx 10.4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we differentiate $h(t)$ with respect to $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.2em} h'(t) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\big[-2t^2+20t+8\big] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -4t+20}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = h(t)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c760d599-f910-4557-b1f6-1de511fb6a68/images/1f252474-3408-41a9-a62f-a5254bf8ee4e/397bd75d8b517ae440b92c4aa69a8d23b9a43a67.svg)


  Hence the maximum height is
$\answer{58 \text{ m}}$
and it is reached after
$\answer{5 \text{ seconds}}$
- Solving the equation $h(t) = 8$ for $t > 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2t^2+20t+8 &= 8 \hspace{8.6em} \\[6pt]
  -2t^2+20t &= 0 \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{12.2em} \answer{t = 10 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 57
list.content: The dietary reference intake (DRI, in grams), $y$, of protein for a sedentary male adult of mass $x$ kg is determined by the equation $y = mx + c$, where $m$ and $c$ are constants. For a male adult of mass $60$ kg the DRI of protein is $69$ grams, and for a male adult of mass $90$ kg the DRI of protein is $91.5$ grams. - Determine the value of $m$ and the value of $c$. [3] - Find the DRI of protein for a male adult of mass $70$ kg. [2] - Suggest a reason why the equation may not be appropriate for determining the DRI of protein for a male child of mass $40$ kg. [2]

list.title: Question 58
list.content: The graph of a quadratic function has a $y$-intercept at A$(0,24)$ and one of its $x$-intercepts is B$(2,0)$. The $x$-coordinate of the vertex of the graph is $4$. The equation of the quadratic function is in the form $y = ax^2+bx+c$. - Write down the value of $c$. [1] - Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4] - Write down the coordinates of the second $x$-intercept of the function. [1]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{c = 24}$
- Using the axis of symmetry formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.4em} 4 &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x = 4$}] \\[6pt]
  b &= -8a \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the coordinates of B, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0 &= a(2)^2 + b(2) + c \\[6pt]
  [\text{from $(1)$ \& part (a)}] \hspace{2em} 0 &= a(2)^2 + (-8a)(2) + 24 \hspace{3.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{8.1em} \answer{a = 2} \\[3pt] \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

  Hence, substituting $a = 2$ in the equation $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= -8(2) \hspace{0.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b = -16} \hspace{1.7em}
  $$

- $\answer{(6,0)}$

list.title: Question 59
list.content: Sarah's investment portfolio, $V(t)$, in Australian dollars (AUD), is modelled by the function $$ V(t) = 64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{k}{100}\right)^t, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0, $$ where $t$ is the number of years since $2019$ and $k$ is a constant. - Find an expression for the value of the investment portfolio in $2020$. Give your answer in the form $a + bk$, where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. [2] Three years later, in $2022$, the value of the investment portfolio is expected to be $74\hspace{0.15em}088$ AUD. - Find the value of $k$. [2] This model is defined for $0 \leq t \leq n$. At $n$ years, the value of the investment portfolio would have doubled since $2019$. - Find the value of $n$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff457177-5def-4306-a827-b5312983770c/images/6ecb8a65-c1f7-4db9-aa27-b8d368274747/70d7f3dfd5326294e23da6bf1d0710b2f53e7027.svg)


  Hence, substituting $t = 1$ in the expression for $V(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} V(1) &= 64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{k}{100}\right) \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 64\hspace{0.15em}000 + 640k}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $V(3) = 74\hspace{0.25em}088$ for $k$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{k}{100}\right)^3 &= 74\hspace{0.25em}088 \hspace{9.3em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{7.8em} \answer{k = 5} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $V(n) = 2\times64\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $n$,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{5}{100}\right)^n &= 128\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.6em} \answer{n \approx 14.2 \text{ years}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 60
list.content: The following table shows the total revenue, $y$, in Australian dollars (AUD), $\text{obtained}$ daily during the first week of January $2020$, by Peppy's Pizza $\text{restaurant}$ and the number of guests, $x$, served. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0b8e05a7-0c33-4aef-a8f9-eaa7da8cacbd/images/5c7e3e73-93f7-4332-8ef8-a9fee762c9a8/9736e8eb9c9cfe8a065bfa8f5344721e7887b704.svg) - - Calculate the Pearson's product-moment correlation coefficient, $r$, for this data. - Hence comment on the result. [4] - Write down the equation of the regression line $y$ on $x$. [2] - Use the line of the regression to estimate the revenue of serving $70$ guests. Give your answer correct to the nearest AUD. [3] Daily maintenance cost for the restaurant is $240$ AUD. Additionally, the cost of serving one guest is $5$ AUD. - Determine if the restaurant makes a profit when serving $45$ guests on a $\text{particular}$ day. [2] - - Write down an expression for the total revenue of serving $x$ guests. - Find an expression for the profit of the restaurant when serving $x$ guests on a particular day. - Find the least number of guests required to be served to result in a profit for the day. [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{r = 0.991}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
  - $\answer{\text{Positive, strong correlation b/n the number of guests and revenue}}$

- $\answer{y = 10.4x - 14.3}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Evaluating $y = 10.4x - 14.3$ for $x = 70$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 10.4(70) - 14.3 \\[6pt] 
  &= 713.7 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 714 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The profit of the restaurant when serving $45$ guests on a
particular day is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
  &= 410 - (240 + 5(45)) \\[6pt]
  &= -55 \text{ AUD} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Hence the restaurant makes a loss when serving only \(45\) guests.}}$
- 
  - $\answer{\mathrm{Revenue} = 10.4x - 14.3}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.4em} \mathrm{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
    &= (10.4x - 14.3) - (240 + 5x) \\[6pt]
    &= 10.4x - 14.3 - 240 - 5x \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 5.4x - 254.3}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $\text{Profit} = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} 5.4x - 254.3 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 47.1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(48\) guests}}$
are required to be served to result in a profit.

list.title: Question 61
list.content: The table below shows the income tax rates in Australia for $2019/2020$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/38e87d71-aa45-4ae1-997c-8168046a7a6b/images/62b3675b-f14c-40c4-a8aa-d70cde20282f/fdc54f4f44cdc2829f72776123b2f9c38299e7c3.svg) - Find the exact amount of tax payable for a person who earns $\$200\hspace{0.15em}000$. [2] - Draw the graph of tax payable versus income on the grid below. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/38e87d71-aa45-4ae1-997c-8168046a7a6b/images/7085a029-658e-46f4-be97-d44b512fce9b/8e8ba36becb38ae96165f6d48e55934a801a7f2e.svg)

we get

  &\answer{= \$63\hspace{0.15em}096}\end{aligned}

list.title: Question 62
list.content: The following table shows the total revenue, $y$, in US dollars (USD), $\text{obtained}$ monthly during the first six months of $2020$, by Law Office of Fox Brothers and the number of clients, $x$, served. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3fada96d-f0c9-41f0-9d39-499c701ec1ba/images/c0269508-9618-4eab-8784-4661a19513ee/e4734e7152b428b88af8a05241306257c07d8464.svg) - - Calculate the Pearson's product-moment correlation coefficient, $r$, for this data. - Hence comment on the result. [4] - Write down the equation of the regression line $y$ on $x$. [2] - Use the line of the regression to estimate the revenue of serving $20$ clients. Give your answer correct to the nearest USD. [3] Monthly operating cost for the law office is $\$2500$. Additionally, the cost of serving each client is $\$200$. - Determine if the law office makes a profit when serving $6$ clients on a $\text{particular}$ month. [2] - - Write down an expression for the total revenue of serving $x$ clients. - Find an expression for the profit of the law office when serving $x$ clients on a particular month. - Find the least number of clients required to be served to result in a profit for the month. [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{r = 0.995}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
  - $\answer{\text{Positive, strong correlation b/n the number of clients and revenue}}$

- $\answer{y = 654x - 541}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Evaluating $y = 654x - 541$ for $x = 20$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 654(20) - 541 \hspace{0.5em} \\[6pt]
  &= 12\hspace{0.15em}539 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 12\hspace{0.15em}539} \end{aligned}
  $$

- The profit of the law office when serving $6$ clients on a
particular month is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} \text{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
  &= 3000 - (2500 + 200(6)) \\[6pt]
  &= -\$700 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Hence the law office makes a loss when serving only \(6\) clients.}}$
- 
  - $\answer{\mathrm{Revenue} = 654x - 541}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.3em} \mathrm{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
    &= (654x - 541) - (2500 + 200x) \\[6pt]
    &= 654x - 541 - 2500 - 200x \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 454x - 3041}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $\text{Profit} = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} 454x - 3041 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 6.70 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(7\) clients}}$
are required to be served to result in a profit.

list.title: Question 64
list.content: The data below shows the price, $y$, in Kazakhstani tenge (KZT), that each bag of wheat flour can be purchased for at a wholesale market in Almaty if $x$ bags are ordered. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/620f11cc-de36-420f-8fd5-6f61bec6fd2e/images/6fdb89eb-7ab4-4f60-a277-9ebc4bccb019/5a253ce60e250108cf649fd1f8dc000abcca0657.svg) - Find an expression for the price, $y$ KZT, of each bag purchased in terms of the number of bags, $x$, ordered. [2] - Hence find the exact total cost of purchasing $250$ bags of wheat flour. [3]
list.markScheme:
- From the data we see that $y$ is determined by the linear equation
$y= mx + c$.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50m + c &= 6500  \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  100m + c &= 6000 \hspace{0.75em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $m$ and $c$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{8.9em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  m &=& -10 \\[6pt]
  c &=& 7000
  \end{array} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{y = -10x + 7000}$
- Evaluating $y = -10x + 7000$ for $x = 250$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} y &= -10(250) + 7000 \\[6pt]
  &= 4500 \text{ KZT}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the total cost of
purchasing $250$ bags of wheat flour is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Total cost} &= 4500(250) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1\hspace{0.15em}125\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ KZT}} \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 65
list.content: The average gasoline price, $P$, in cents per gallon, in USA $2019$ can be modelled by the function $$ \hspace{1em} P(t) = a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t+\ang{90}) + b, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 365, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in days, since New Year's Eve $2018$. Part of the graph of $y = P(t)$ is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/80d14f42-a9e9-49a9-8f34-f3ad09b8c895/images/f323592f-678a-4312-aa48-55fd411bb4ce/eba99471e7227e6ca3549b0274fdd498563d4121.svg) - Write down the value of $b$. [1] The average price of gasoline at the end of $14$th of January, $2019$ was $328$ cents per gallon. - Show that the value of $a$ is equal to 56. [2] - Hence calculate: - the average gasoline price on the $14$th of February, $2019$; - the minimum and maximum average prices of gasoline in USA $2019$. [3] The cycle of average gasoline prices repeats every T days. - Determine the value of T.[2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{300}$
- Solving the equation $P(14) = 328$ for $a$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 14+\ang{90}) + 300 &= 328 \hspace{10em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos \ang{300} + 300 &= 328 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.2em} \answer{a = 56} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 31+14 = 45$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P(45) &= 56\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 45+\ang{90}) + 300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 340 \text{ cents per gallon}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max average prices are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P_{\text{min}} &= 56(-1)+300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 244 \text{ cents per gallon}} \hspace{3em} \\[15pt]
    P_{\text{max}} &= 56(+1)+300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 356 \text{ cents per gallon}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/80d14f42-a9e9-49a9-8f34-f3ad09b8c895/images/95fdb075-ae11-4e91-9c51-45fed90c3c09/0189e79cc182a1047199d3fb9dc1b367d698bb2d.svg)


  Hence we find
$\answer{\text{T} = 24}$

list.title: Question 66
list.content: Part of the graph of $y = f(x)$ is shown below. The point A$(3,4)$ lies on the graph. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bc997ee1-157a-4954-840a-c7cf3a649ca9/images/40752509-d462-43d8-b4eb-2c65b6d2b48f/cc26169f3e878b541f9e30065e66509e180ee603.svg) - Write down the value of $f(3)$. [1] The tangent line $L$ to the graph of $y = f(x)$ at point A has equation $y = 3x - 5$. - Find the equation of the normal line $N$ to the graph of $y = f(x)$ at point A. Give your answer in the form $ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3] - Draw the lines $L$ and $N$ on the same grid above, labelling the intercepts with the axes. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{f(3) = 4}$
- The gradient of $N$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.7em} m_{N} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $N \perp L$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient
formula with A$(3,4)$ and $m = -1/3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]
  y - 4 &= -\dfrac{1}{3}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 3) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{1.0em} 3(y - 4) &= -(x - 3) \\[11pt]
  3y - 12 &= -x + 3 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x + 3y - 15 = 0} \hspace{4.65em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L:&\hspace{1em} y = 3x - 5 \\[10pt] 
  \text{$x$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{B}(5/3,0) \\[10pt]
  \text{$y$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{C}(0,-5)\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N:&\hspace{1em} y = -\dfrac{1}{3}x + 5 \\[6pt] 
  \text{$x$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{D}(15,0) \\[10pt]
  \hspace{1.1em} \text{$y$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{E}(0,5)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we draw the lines $L$ and $N$ on the same grid below,
indicating the points B and E, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bc997ee1-157a-4954-840a-c7cf3a649ca9/images/73281b15-cfe0-4b6f-854a-9bef91565be1/a6912eec889f05ce26fa48c17eb09f173f2604d9.svg)

list.title: Question 67
list.content: The number of users on a new social network in $2018$ was $320\hspace{0.15em}000$. One year later, in $2019$, the number of users on this network is estimated to be $350\hspace{0.15em}000$. The number of the users on this network, $N$, can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} N(t) = 320\hspace{0.15em}000\times b^t, \hspace{0.5em} t\geq0, \end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the number of years since $2018$ and $b$ is a constant. - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Estimate the number of the users on this network there will be in $2023$.[2] - Forecast the year for which the number of the social network users reaches one million. Give your answer correct to the nearest year. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c0462e85-e9f3-4564-b103-1800a0e6c31a/images/6fd93ccd-3403-459a-b1d0-cc108da6027c/033cf3beecde613f81a96d293306464dcb68241a.svg)


  Hence, solving the equation $N(1) = 350\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $b$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  320\hspace{0.15em}000\times b &= 350\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{4.4em} \\[9pt]
  b &= \dfrac{350\hspace{0.15em}000}{320\hspace{0.15em}000} \\[6pt]
  b &= \dfrac{35}{32} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b \approx 1.09} \hspace{1.4em}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c0462e85-e9f3-4564-b103-1800a0e6c31a/images/84b094eb-d9dd-4085-b69d-76fef087f129/74c77aa092bfa1ac875f40785f7097708883e3e2.svg)


  Hence, evaluating $N(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} N(5) &= 320\hspace{0.15em}000\times \left(\dfrac{35}{32}\right)^5 \\[4pt]
  &\approx 500\hspace{0.15em}888 \\[10pt]
  &\answer{\approx 501\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ users}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Note: Using a rounded answer from part (a) will produce a different answer. It is very important to use unrounded answers in subsequent parts unless otherwise stated!
- Solving the equation $N(t) = 1\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.15em}000$
for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.75em} 320\hspace{0.15em}000\times \left(\dfrac{35}{32}\right)^t &= 1\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 12.7 \text{ years} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we determine the years corresponding to $t = 12$ and $t=13$, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c0462e85-e9f3-4564-b103-1800a0e6c31a/images/1245122b-6dac-4c68-8899-ca6456b3869e/a616f6ab254b62e363c8d49827ba23ea9d06f1c6.svg)


  Hence the number of network users reaches one million
$\answer{\text{during } 2030}$

list.title: Question 68
list.content: The downward speed, $V$, in metres per second, gained by a skydiver during a jump is modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} V(t) = 56 - 56\times3^{-\frac{t}{4}}, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$, in seconds, is the time for which the skydiver is free falling in the air. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c78843c2-7d92-4862-b0e4-d8852e751513/images/0c7e427a-797f-41b5-a346-4d216bf8de4c/d3ee9eadbfc138be37002b3f29e50508f36ba8d9.svg) - Write down the downward speed of the skydiver at $t=0$. [1] The line $L$ is the horizontal asymptote to the graph. - Determine the equation of $L$. [2] The skydiver starts to feel no acceleration when he reaches the speed of $55$ metres per second. - Find the time it takes for the skydiver to reach this speed. Give your answer correct to the nearest second. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $V(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} V(0) &= 56-56\times 3^0 \\[6pt]
  &= 56-56 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 0 \text{ m$/$s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.2em} \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} V(t) &= \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} \big[56 - 56\times3^{-\frac{t}{4}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 56 - 0 \hspace{2em} [\text{since $3^{-\frac{t}{4}} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$}] \\[10pt]
  &= 56 \text{ m$/$s}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L$ is
$\answer{y = 56}$
- Solving the equation $V(t) = 55$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.5em} 56 - 56\times3^{-\frac{t}{4}} &= 55 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 14.7 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it takes
$\answer{15 \text{ seconds}}$
to reach the speed of $55$ metres per second.

list.title: Question 69
list.content: At the start 2001, a team of zoologists introduced a new species of rabbit onto a large island. $1000$ rabbits were initially introduced and there were $1728$ rabbits at the start of 2004. The size of the population of the species, $N$, $t$ years after the start of 2001, can be modelled by the following function $$ N(t) = p \times q^t, \quad \qquad t\geq 0 $$ - - Show that the value of $p$ is $1000$. - Verify that $q=1.2$.[2] - State the annual growth rate of the population as a percentage. [1] - Use the model to predict the population size at the start of 2011.[2] In 2012, the team observed that the growth rate of the rabbit species was changing and that the overall population was now in decline. Upon investigation, they found that the rabbits had became the prey of a new type of snake on the island. Zoologists adjusted their model to the following new function, where $t$ is still the number of years after the start of 2001. $$ N(t) = 1380 \times (0.87)^{(t-12)} \quad \qquad t\geq 12 $$ - Use this model to find the size of the population at the start of 2019.[2] - Find the year in which the population of the species will first drop below $200$.[3] - In the period from 2013 onwards, find the number of complete years in which the size of the population of the species was greater than or equal to $800$.[3] At the start of 2020, the remaining population of the species was transferred to another island along with $300$ more rabbits. The team of zoologists now expect the population growth will recover and will increase at a rate of $10\%$ per year. - Estimate the size of the population at the start of 2030. [3]

list.title: Question 71
list.content: The average petrol price, $P$, in cents per litre, in Australia $2019$ can be modelled by the function $$ \hspace{1em} P(t) = a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{10}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + b, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 365, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in days, since New Year's Eve $2018$. Part of the graph of $y = P(t)$ is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f4e9707a-58e9-43d3-a5cf-acd20baf6f9d/images/72a07772-6b2a-48cc-aea3-9d4440fb053e/3686d49d230056274ce98d6aa0d4dd1872a85c82.svg) - Write down the value of $b$. [1] The average price of petrol on the $21$st of January, $2019$ was $139$ cents per litre. - Show the value of $a$ is equal to 12. [2] - Hence calculate: - the average petrol price on the $10$th of February, $2019$; - the minimum and maximum average prices of petrol in Australia $2019$.[3] The cycle of average petrol prices repeats every T days. - Determine the value of T.[2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{145}$
- Solving the equation $P(21) = 139$ for $a$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{10}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 21) + 145 &= 139 \hspace{7.4em} \\[6pt]
  a\sin 2\ang{10} + 145 &= 139 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.2em} \answer{a = 12} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 31+10 = 41$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P(41) &= 12\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{10}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 41) + 145 \hspace{1.8em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 154 \text{ cents per litre}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The min and max values of the sine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max average prices are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P_{\text{min}} &= 12(-1)+145 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 133 \text{ cents per litre}} \hspace{3em} \\[15pt]
    P_{\text{max}} &= 12(+1)+145 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 157 \text{ cents per litre}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f4e9707a-58e9-43d3-a5cf-acd20baf6f9d/images/70f1d702-31c5-4aa3-bc1c-81a56736356c/30c06c40c5cf2c5d8e88197edf49a8900fddc76e.svg)


  Hence we find
$\answer{\text{T} = 36}$

list.title: Question 72
list.content: A healthcare company is designing a new deodorant stick that can be modelled by the shape of a parabola as the top, vertical lines as the sides and a horizontal line as the base, on the $x$-axis. The parabola has end points at $(0,7)$ and $(5,7)$, and vertex at $(2.5,8)$. This design is shown in the diagram below. All distances are measured in centimetres. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0c28bf3a-d07a-4efc-8f72-f3bbd5583b2f/images/b0822073-b2c4-4e24-96eb-f3c9ee8d0169/AI1006a.PNG) The quadratic curve can be expressed in the form $y=ax^2+bx+c$ for $0\leq x \leq 5$. - - Find the value of $c$. - Using the points $(2.5,8)$ and $(5,7)$, write two equations in $a$ and $b$. - Hence, find the equation of the quadratic curve. [5] - Find the area of the shaded region in the deodorant design.[3]

list.title: Question 73
list.content: When a coin is thrown from the top of a skyscraper, its height above the ground after $t$ seconds is given by $s(t) = at^2 + bt + c$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres. After $1$ second, the coin is $179.3$ m above the ground; after $2$ seconds, $188.2$ m; after $6$ seconds, $159.8$ m. - - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3] - Find the height of the skyscraper. [1] - Find the time it takes for the coin to hit the ground. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    
    \answer{\begin{array}{rcccccl}
    a &+& b &+& c &=& 179.3 \\[3pt]
    4a &+& 2b &+& c &=& 188.2 \\[3pt]
    36a &+& 6b &+& c &=& 159.8
    \end{array}} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we express the system of linear equations $(1)$ as a matrix
equation, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45dabcef-b9ef-4f62-87fe-f37674153ffe/images/3205da83-27aa-4a59-acd7-c2722a0e3a9c/13c88ece23638748c2e63548748180dced5a9e26.svg)


    Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45dabcef-b9ef-4f62-87fe-f37674153ffe/images/918f55b1-39bd-4ecb-8146-97ebf200d357/8c737a936777a47edd03c6c7de7ba744071b76ba.svg)


    Hence we find
$\answer{a = -3.2, \hspace{0.25em} b = 18.5, \hspace{0.25em} c = 164}$

- Evaluating $s(t)$ at $t = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.9em} s(0) &= -3.2(0)^2 + 18.5(0) + 164 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 164 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $s(t) = 0$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -3.2t^2 + 18.5t + 164 &= 0 \hspace{10.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.5em} \answer{t \approx 10.6 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 74
list.content: A population of $40$ rabbits are brought to an island at the end of December, $2018$. The population, $P$, of rabbits on the island can be modelled by the logistic function $$ \begin{aligned} P(t) &= \dfrac{M}{1 + Ce^{-0.3t}}\hspace{0.05em},\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the number of months that have passed since New Year Eve $2019$. After $12$ months, the population of rabbits on the island is increased to $1423$. - Find the value of $M$ and the value of $C$. [4] - Write down the largest population of rabbits that the island will ever be able to accommodate.[1] - Hence calculate the number of months it takes for the population of rabbits to reach half of its largest population. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $P(0) = 40$ for $M$ (in terms of $C$), we
have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{M}{1 + Ce^{-0.3(0)}} &= 40 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{M}{1 + C} &= 40 \\[12pt]
  M &= 40(1+C) \hspace{2.5em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $P(12) = 1423$ for $C$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.6em} \dfrac{M}{1 + Ce^{-0.3(12)}} &= 1423 \\[4pt]
  \dfrac{40(1+C)}{1 + Ce^{-0.3(12)}} &= 1423 \hspace{3em} [\text{by $(1)$}] \\[10pt]
  C &\approx 1236.65 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{C \approx 1240} \hspace{0.8em}
  $$

  Hence, substituting $C \approx 1236.65$ in the equation $(1)$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} M &= 40(1+1236.65) \\[6pt]
  &= 49\hspace{0.15em}506 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 49\hspace{0.15em}500}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{49\hspace{0.15em}500}$
- Solving the equation $P(t) = 49\hspace{0.15em}500(0.5)$ for $t$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{49\hspace{0.15em}500}{1 + 1240e^{-0.3t}} &= 24\hspace{0.15em}750 \hspace{5.8em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.6em}  \answer{t = 23.7 \text{ months}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 75
list.content: Gordon is cooking steaks for his friends Gino and Fred. When Gordon removes the first steak from the grill, the rate at which the internal temperature decreases can be modelled by the function: $$ \begin{align*} T_1 (t)=ke^{-0.0811t}+20 \end{align*} $$ Where $T_1$ is the temperature of the steak in $^\circ \mathrm{C}$, $t$ minutes after it has been removed from the grill. $k$ is a positive constant. At the time the first steak is removed from the grill, it has an internal temperature of $65^\circ \mathrm{C}$. - Find the value of $k$.[2] - State the equation of the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $y=T_1(t)$. Interpret this in context. [2] Gordon wants to let the steak rest until it reaches an internal temperature of $50^\circ \mathrm{C}$. - Calculate the length of time the steak should rest for.[2] At the exact time Gordon removes the first steak from the grill, he adds two more steaks to the grill to cook. The rate at which the internal temperature of the steaks increases on the grill can be modelled by the function: $$ \begin{align*} T_2 (t)=180-160e^{-0.0472t} \end{align*} $$ Where $T_2$ is the temperature of the steaks in $^\circ \mathrm{C}$, $t$ minutes after they have been placed on the grill. - State the equation of the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $y=T_2(t)$. Interpret this in context. [2] - Determine the time at which all three steaks have the same internal temperature. [3] Gino wants his steak rare, and so Gordon removes it from the grill after $6.5$ minutes. - Calculate the internal temperature of Gino’s steak when it is taken off the grill. [2] Fred wants his steak well done, which means an internal temperature of $75^\circ \mathrm{C}$. - Calculate how much longer Fred’s steak will stay on the grill after Gino’s is removed.[3]

list.title: Question 76
list.content: The graph shows the curve of a quadratic function of the form $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + 90$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6886819b-3fbd-43d3-95f6-61cf97d171c1/images/abf35098-dbcc-4ba6-a3af-f17c013fd694/e02d6931ce58420fa7c9cbe422473aefce55e151.svg) - Write down the equation for the axis of symmetry of the curve. [2] - Hence, or otherwise, find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [3] - Find the $y$-coordinate of the vertex of the curve. [1]
list.markScheme:
- The axis of symmetry intersects the $x$-axis midway between the
$x$-intercepts.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.15em} x &= \dfrac{-5+9}{2} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.4em} \answer{x = 2}
  $$

- Using the coordinates of A, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-5) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  a(-5)^2 + b(-5) + 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  25a - 5b &= -90 \hspace{1em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the
coordinates of B, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(9) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.6em} a(9)^2 + b(9) + 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  81a + 9b &= -90 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system
of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.4em} \answer{a = -2}\hspace{0.75em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.75em}\answer{b = 8}\hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- The vertex of the curve lies on the axis of symmetry.
Hence, evaluating $f(x)$ for $x = 2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.8em} f(2) &= -2(2)^2 + 8(2) + 90 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 98}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 77
list.content: Radiocarbon dating can be used to estimate the age of an artifact made of wood. Archeologists take a sample of wood from the artifact and measure the ratio, $r$, of Carbon-$14$ in the sample to Carbon-$14$ in a living wood. The age, $t$, in years, is then estimated by using the equation $$ \begin{aligned} \hspace{14.5em} t &= -\dfrac{6000}{\ln 2}\times\ln r, \hspace{8em} [\text{Age Model}]\end{aligned} $$ where $0.01 < r < 1$. A team of underwater archeologists found an ancient wooden shipwreck deep down in the Black Sea. A sample of wood is taken from the shipwreck to determine its age. - Find the age of the shipwreck if $r = 0.75$. [2] In all wood samples, Carbon-$14$ decays over time. If $r < 0.01$, there is insufficient amount of Carbon-$14$ left in the sample wood for its age estimate calculated by the age model to be reliable. - Find the oldest sample of wood for its age estimate found by the age model would just cease to be reliable. Give your answer to the nearest $10\hspace{0.15em}000$ years.[2] - Using the age model, express $r$ in terms of $t$. [2] - Hence find $r$ when $t = 7500$, giving your answer correct to $2$ decimal places. [2]

list.title: Question 78
list.content: A farmer is going to fence two equal adjacent parcels of land. These parcels share one side (which also requires fencing) as shown in the following diagram. The farmer has only $80$ metres of fence. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/942728b4-5d3b-49b2-b0df-1f2bcfdbdfa5/images/942ca9e0-fea9-4897-abd7-6e372c3eaafb/580f23d360211ad7dd2c45e79d30c7d9c7d24f56.svg) - Write down the equation for the total length of the fence, $80\,$m, in terms of $x$ and $y$. [1] - Write down the total area of both parcels of land in terms of $x$. [2] - Find the maximum area, in m$^2$, of one parcel of land. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{80 = 3x + 4y}$
- The total area of both parcels of land in terms of $x$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} A(x) &= x(2y) \\[18pt]
  &= 2xy \\[11pt]
  &= 2x\left(\dfrac{80 - 3x}{4}\right) \hspace{3em} [\text{from part (a)}] \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 40x - \dfrac{3}{2}x^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = A(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
