  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/942728b4-5d3b-49b2-b0df-1f2bcfdbdfa5/images/c56e4bf6-38aa-4ad7-9220-a283e89a5d6e/d34855549a850484b1041b3153951956e33882fa.svg)


  Hence the maximum area of one parcel of land is
$\dfrac{266.67}{2} \approx$
$\answer{133 \text{ m}^2}$

list.title: Question 79
list.content: The frequency, $f$, in hertz (Hz), and the period, $T$, in seconds, of a wave are related by the equation $$ \hspace{-2em} f = \dfrac{1}{T} \\[3pt] $$ An electronic signal is sent out with amplitude $3$ and frequency $200$ Hz. The strength of this signal at time $t$ seconds is given by $$ S_1 = 3\sin(bt) $$ - Find the value of $b$, giving your answer in terms of $\pi$. [2] A second signal of equal strength is sent out with a time delay of $2$ milliseconds. The strength of the second signal at time $t$ seconds is given by $$ S_2 = 3\sin(b\hspace{0.05em}(t - c)) \hspace{1em} $$ - Write down the value of $c$. [1] The strength of the sum of the two signals at time $t$ seconds is given by $$ \hspace{3.5em} S_3 = 3\sin(bt) + 3\sin(b\hspace{0.05em}(t - c)) $$ - Draw the graphs of $S_1$, $S_2$ and $S_3$ versus $t$, for $0 \leq t \leq 0.01$, on the same axes.[4]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= \dfrac{2\pi}{T} \\[6pt]
  &= 2\pi f \\[10pt]
  &= 2\pi(200) \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 400\pi}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{0.002 \text{ seconds}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} S_1 &= 3\sin(400\pi t) \\[6pt]
  S_2 &= 3\sin(400\pi(t-0.002)) \\[6pt]
  S_3 &= 3\sin(400\pi t)+3\sin(400\pi(t-0.002))\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we
draw the graphs of $S_1$, $S_2$ and $S_3$ versus $t$, for
$0 \leq t \leq 0.01$, on the same axes, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bfbddd54-1721-4ba9-8e4d-bbff7c700dc7/images/4d1bfeeb-8b4e-4e69-a027-b8d8c7486c42/0df5ba0b08b1afb94d525de7b9f106155190849e.svg)

list.title: Question 80
list.content: A population of goldfish decreases exponentially. The size of the population, $P$, after $t$ days is modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} P(t) = 8000\times2^{-t} + 100, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0. \\ \end{aligned} $$ - Write down the exact size of the initial population. [1] - Find the size of the population after $5$ days. [2] - Calculate the time it will take for the size of the population to decrease to $120$.[2] The population will stabilize when it reaches a size of $n$. - Write down the value of $n$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.7em} P(0) &= 8000\times2^0 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &= 8000 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8100}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.3em} P(5) &= 8000\times2^{-5} + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 350}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 120$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  8000\times2^{-t} + 100 &= 120 \hspace{6.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{14.2em} \answer{t = 8.64 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.9em} \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} P(t) &= \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} \big[8000\times2^{-t} + 100\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 0+100 \hspace{2em} [\text{since $2^{-t} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$}] \\[10pt]
  &= 100 \text{ days}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the value of $n$ is
$\answer{100}$

list.title: Question 81
list.content: The half-life, $T$, in years, of a radioactive isotope can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} T(k) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{k}{100}\right)}, \hspace{0.5em} 0 < k < 100,\end{aligned} $$ where $k$ is the decay rate, in percent, per year of the isotope. - The decay rate of Hydrogen-$3$ is $5.5$ % per year. Find its half-life.[2] The half-life of Uranium-$232$ (U-$232$) is $68.9$ years. A sample containing $250$ grams of U-$232$ is obtained and stored as a side product of a nuclear fuel cycle. - Find the decay rate per year of U-$232$. [2] - Find the amount of U-$232$ left in the sample after: - $68.9$ years; - $100$ years. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(k)$ for $k = 5.5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  T(5.5) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{5.5}{100}\right)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 12.3 \text{ years}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(k) = 68.9$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{r}{100}\right)} &= 68.9 \hspace{6.05em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.3em} \answer{k = 1.00\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{125 \text{ grams}}$
  - We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 250$ and
the $\text{common}$ ratio $r = (1 - 1.00/100) = 0.99$.
    Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n=101$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    u_{101} &= u_1r^{101-1} \\[6pt]
    &= 250\hspace{0.05em}(0.99)^{101-1} \hspace{0.2em} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 91.5 \text{ grams}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 82
list.content: The decibel scale measures how loud a sound is to the human ear. The decibel rating, $\mathrm{dB}$, of a sound can be modelled as a function of its sound intensity, $I$, as shown by the equation $$ \begin{align*} \mathrm{dB} = 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120 \end{align*} $$ Where $I$ is measured in Watts per square metre $(\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2)$ and $I>0$. The pain threshold for the average human ear is $130\,\mathrm{dB}$. - Show that the pain threshold is reached at exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$. [1] Amelia has a diesel generator that has a sound intensity of $1 \times 10^{-3.5}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$. - Determine the decibel rating of Amelia's generator. [2] Amelia is considering replacing her old diesel generator and has discovered a quieter petrol generator that has a decibel rating of $50\,\mathrm{dB}$. - Determine the sound intensity of the petrol generator. Give your answer in the form $a \times 10^k$ where $1 \leq a < 10$ and $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.[2] - Find how many times greater the sound intensity of the diesel generator is compared to the petrol generator.[2]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $I=10$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,10 + 120 = 130
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The pain threshold of $130\,\mathrm{dB}$ is reached at a sound intensity of exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$.
- Substituting $I=1 \times 10^{-3.5}$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{dB} &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,\left(1 \times 10^{-3.5}\right) + 120 \\[8pt]
  &= 85
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{Amelia's generator has a rating of }85\,\mathrm{dB}.}$
- Substituting $\mathrm{dB}=50$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And we know that $0<I<10^{-3.5}$. Using the numeric solver on the G.D.C. we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{nSolve}\big(50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120\,,I\,\big)\,|\,0<I<10^{-3.5} \\[8pt]
  I &= 0.0000001
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{The sound intensity of the petrol generator is } 1 \times 10^{-7}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2.}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \dfrac{1 \times 10^{-3.5}}{1 \times 10^{-7}} \approx 3162
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The sound intensity of the diesel generator is approximately 3160 times greater than the sound intensity of the petrol generator.

list.title: Question 83
list.content: The half-life, $T$, in days, of a radioactive isotope can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} T(k) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{k}{100}\right)}, \hspace{0.5em} 0 < k < 100,\end{aligned} $$ where $k$ is the decay rate, in percent, per day of the isotope. - The decay rate of Gold-$196$ is $6.2$ % per day. Find its half-life.[2] The half-life of Phosphorus-$32$ (P-$32$) is $14.3$ days. A sample containing $120$ grams of P-$32$ is produced and stored in a biochemistry laboratory. - Find the decay rate per day of P-$32$. [2] - Find the amount of P-$32$ left in the sample after: - $14.3$ days; - $50$ days. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(k)$ for $k = 6.2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  T(6.2) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{6.2}{100}\right)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 10.8 \text{ days}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(k) = 14.3$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{r}{100}\right)} &= 14.3 \hspace{6.05em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.25em} \answer{k = 4.73\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{60 \text{ grams}}$
  - We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 120$ and
the $\text{common}$ ratio $r = (1 - 4.73/100) = 0.9527$.
    Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n=51$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.8em} u_{51} &= u_1r^{51-1} \\[6pt]
    &= 120\hspace{0.05em}(0.9527)^{51-1} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 10.6 \text{ grams}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 84
list.content: The position, $s$, in metres, of a cyclist on a straight track can be modelled by the piecewise function $$ s(t) = \left\{\begin{array}{lcl} at^2, && 0 \leq t < 6.5, \\[6pt] 0.102t^2+2.48t-12, && 6.5 \leq t < 10, \\[6pt] mt-62, && t \geq 10, \end{array} \right. \\[4pt] $$ where $t$ is the time, in seconds, and $a, m \in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $a = 0.1995$ correct to $4$ significant figures. [2] - Find the exact value of $m$. [2] - Calculate the time it takes for the cyclist to travel: - $15$ m; - $200$ m. [4] - Draw the graph of $s$ versus $t$, showing the position of the cyclist during the first $20$ seconds. [3] - Determine the time interval when the cyclist is travelling fastest. [1] - Hence find its maximum speed, giving your answer in kilometres per hour.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The piecewise function $s$ must be continuous at $6.5$.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} a(6.5)^2 &= 0.102(6.5)^2+2.48(6.5)-12 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{4.9em} \answer{a \approx 0.1995} \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- The piecewise function $s$ must be continuous at $10$.
Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.6em} m(10)-62 &= 0.102(10)^2+2.48(10)-12 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{6em} \answer{m = 8.5} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Evaluating $s(t)$ for $t = 6.5$ and $t = 10$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.5em} s(6.5) &= 0.102(6.5)^2+2.48(6.5)-12 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 8.43 \text{ m} \\[9pt]
  s(10) &= 8.5(10)-62 \\[6pt]
  &= 23 \text{ m}\end{aligned}
  $$

  
  - Hence solving the equation $s(t) = 15$ for $6.5 < t < 10$, we
get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    0.102t^2+2.48t-12 &= 15 \hspace{15em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{8.4em} \answer{t \approx 8.15 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
    $$

  - Hence solving the equation $s(t) = 200$ for $t > 10$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    8.5t-62 &= 200 \hspace{9.7em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{8.4em} \answer{t \approx 30.8 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
    $$


- If we draw the graph of $s$ versus $t$, for $0 \leq t \leq 20$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ec58a4fe-1cff-4db1-9142-c1caafdc49f4/images/84cadd48-cb0d-4e53-b1ff-4e33fa84d6ab/616ac32f24b562cc41bdf637d012fe75a106e91e.svg)


- The graph of $s$ versus $t$ is steepest (highest speed) on the
interval  $\answer{t \geq 10}$
- Hence the maximum speed of the cyclist is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.2em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}s}{\mathrm{d}t} &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\big[8.5t-62\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 8.5 \text{ m sec$^{-1}$} \\[9pt]
  &= 8.5\times3.6 \text{ km h$^{-1}$} \hspace{2em} [1 \text{ m sec}^{-1} = 3.6 \text{ km h}^{-1}] \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 30.6 \text{ km h$^{-1}$}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 85
list.content: The axis of symmetry of the graph of a quadratic function has equation $x = \dfrac{3}{2}$. - Draw the axis of symmetry on the grid below. [1] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/8127e62b-8e3d-4e6a-800c-1ba598460cd3/095afe930760d162dfc8b9c36b42836af719a0ca.svg) The graph of the quadratic function intersects the $x$-axis at the point P$(-1,0)$. There is a second point, Q , at which the graph of the quadratic function intersects the $x$-axis. - Mark and label P and Q on the grid above. [1] The graph of the quadratic function has equation $y = -x^2+bx+c$, where $b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$. - - Find the value of $b$ and the value of $c$. - Find the coordinates of the vertex, M. - Draw the graph of the quadratic function on the grid above. [4]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the axis of symmetry on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/675f3abb-838e-4191-9b73-48d678ab9e7c/251642e55ba01124027bed7ddba72f11d48d8750.svg)


- The $x$-coordinate of $Q$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x &= \dfrac{3}{2} + \left[\dfrac{3}{2}-(-1)\right] \\[6pt]
  &= 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we mark and label P and Q on the grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/ad959939-6aee-4367-b94d-7bb2b0d330f5/1fa563586fbd8e498bbc0f6a90199f2a3a99e7f7.svg)


- 
  - Using the coordinates of P, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.1em} 0 &= -(-1)^2 + b(-1) + c \\[6pt]
    0 &= -1 - b + c \\[6pt]
    1 &= -b + c \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Using the coordinates of
Q, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.6em} 0 &= -(4)^2 + b(4) + c \\[6pt]
    0 &= -16 + 4b + c \\[6pt]
    16 &= 4b + c \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, solving the system
of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $b$ and $c$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10em} \answer{b = 3}\hspace{0.75em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.75em}\answer{c = 4}\hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $y = -x^2 + 3x + 4$ for $x = 3/2 = 1.5$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.2em} y &= -(1.5)^2 + 3(1.5) + 4 \\[6pt]
    &= 6.25\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of M are
$\answer{(1,5,6.25)}$
  - If we draw the graph of $y = -x^2 + 3x + 4$ on the grid below,
we obtain

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/35a967a1-1150-4aa0-a4fd-7d63f734e780/db963f9fd832653990678f1ba763db2a3974d991.svg)

list.title: Question 86
list.content: When a ball is thrown from the top of a tall building, its height above the ground after $t$ seconds is given by $s(t) = at^2 + bt + c\,,$ where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres. After $1$ second, the ball is $84.3$ m above the ground; after $2$ seconds, $93.9$ m; after $8$ seconds, $42.3$ m. - - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Use matrices to find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3] - Find the height of the building. [1] - Find the time it takes for the ball to hit the ground. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    
    \answer{\begin{array}{rcccccl}
    a &+& b &+& c &=& 84.3 \\[3pt]
    4a &+& 2b &+& c &=& 93.9 \\[3pt]
    64a &+& 8b &+& c &=& 42.3
    \end{array}} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we express the system of linear equations $(1)$ as a matrix
equation, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fa6bc1e0-527f-4b17-bf69-2b0fc42d8867/images/865960d0-98ce-4b87-a675-6a46a2ee65ce/b40b58be9e04029307e50815631013b0e434f45c.svg)


    Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fa6bc1e0-527f-4b17-bf69-2b0fc42d8867/images/1b3b62dd-72c9-42d4-8867-f02c938bd983/04caede963f7db2aac1bc0812ea44cf5b6a29875.svg)


    Hence we find
$\answer{a = -2.6, \hspace{0.25em} b = 17.4, \hspace{0.25em} c = 69.5}$

- Evaluating $s(t)$ at $t = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.2em} s(0) &= -2.6(0)^2 + 17.4(0) + 69.5 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 69.5 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $s(t) = 0$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2.6t^2 + 17.4t + 69.5 &= 0 \hspace{10.8em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.6em} \answer{t \approx 9.50 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 87
list.content: The tides at the Port of Bristol, UK, were observed by a student. On a particular day, the range between the lowest and highest tides is $10.6$ m and the time difference between high tides is $12.2$ hours. The first highest tide occurs at $8$:$12$ am and is $12.5$ m high. The height, $H$, in metres, of the tides can be modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} H &= a\sin\hspace{0.1em}(b\hspace{0.1em}(t-c)) + d, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Write down the value of: - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Find the smallest possible value of $c$, given $c > 0$. [2] - Hence draw the graph of $H$ versus $t$, for $0 \leq t \leq 24$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    a &= \dfrac{10.6}{2} \hspace{3.4em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 5.3}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.4em} d &= \dfrac{12.5+(12.5-10.6)}{2} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 7.2}\end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $H$ is $12.2$ hours.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} b &= \dfrac{2\pi}{12.2} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.515}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation
$a\sin\hspace{0.1em}(b\hspace{0.1em}(8.2-c)) + d = 12.5$ for the
smallest $c > 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5.3\sin\hspace{0.1em}(0.515\hspace{0.1em}(8.2-c)) + 7.2 = 12.5 \hspace{10.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{12em} \answer{c \approx 5.15} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we draw the graph of
$H = 5.3\sin\hspace{0.1em}(0.515\hspace{0.1em}(t-5.15)) + 7.2$
versus $t$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/02542410-de4e-45d3-bf51-c998e419f7c0/images/7614d96a-d12f-4438-820c-1e79fcc211a6/b2f8746d367fe8d39e25915d6f9b5408ac78e4cb.svg)

list.title: Question 88
list.content: A hot apple pie was taken out of the oven and left cooling on the bench. The $\text{temperature}$ of the kitchen is $19$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. This situation can be modelled by the exponential function $T = a + b\big(k^{-t}\big)$, where $T$ is the temperature of the $\text{apple}$ pie, in $\text{\textdegree{C}}$, and $t$ is the number of minutes for which the apple pie has been on the bench in the kitchen. A sketch of the situation is given below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1a60d715-c424-44cb-8944-85a330b2888c/images/7e03cf5a-bd9f-4377-9abc-d311967031fb/8b700a3ae9a0f49f95d8ab1106661a5c84fe1ddf.svg) - Explain why $a = 19$. [2] Initially, at $t = 0$, the temperature of the apple pie is $180$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Find the value of $b$. [2] After being left cooling on the bench for one minute, the temperature of the apple pie is $159$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Show that $k = 1.15$. [2] - Find the temperature of the apple pie five minutes after it has been left cooling on the bench. [2] - Find the total time needed for the apple pie to reach a temperature of $30$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. Give your answer in minutes and seconds, correct to the nearest second. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1a60d715-c424-44cb-8944-85a330b2888c/images/b39e9049-ef3b-49ee-833b-90b8d18f7d54/1fd4fa4206d204d02ea08ff6cea05417465e9ca9.svg)


  On the other hand, we know the temperature of the apple pie cannot
fall below the temperature of the kitchen.
  Hence we must have $a = 19$.
- When $t = 0$, we have $T = 180$.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  19 + b\big(k^{0}\big) &= 180 \hspace{3.3em} \\[6pt]
  19 + b &= 180 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.5em} \answer{b = 161} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- When $t = 1$, we have $T = 159$.
Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  19 + 161\big(k^{-1}\big) &= 159 \hspace{5em} \\[6pt]
  19 +  \dfrac{161}{k} &= 159 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.65em} \answer{k = 1.15} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Evaluating $T = 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-t}\big)$ for $t = 5$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} T &= 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-t}\big) \\[6pt]
  &= 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-5}\big) \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 99.0 \text{\hspace{0.15em}\textdegree{C}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T = 30$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-t}\big) &= 30 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 19.2006 \text{ min} \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{1.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.75em} \answer{t \approx 19 \text{ min} + 12 \text{ sec}} \hspace{2.5em} [(0.2006)(60) \approx 12.0]
  $$

list.title: Question 89
list.content: The downward speed, $V$, in metres per second, of a skydiver $t$ seconds after a jump from a plane is modelled by the piecewise function $$ \begin{aligned} V(t) &= \left\{ \begin{array}{lcl} 60 - \dfrac{K}{t+1}, && 0 \leq t < T, \\[15pt] 12 + \dfrac{46}{t-28}, && t \geq T. \end{array} \right.\end{aligned} $$ - Show that $K = 60$. [2] - Draw the graphs of $y = 60 - \dfrac{60}{t+1}$, for $t \geq 0$, and $y = 12 + \dfrac{46}{t-28}$, for $t > 28$, on the grid below. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2df6984d-0273-4410-8b2b-ac32d48ec20c/images/55d9f90c-36a2-4705-a8c9-87a33f526aef/82e862a110791fe827f0532a883ee15963d674c3.svg) - Find the time $T$ at which the skydiver opened their parachute. [2] - Calculate the speed of the skydiver after: - $10$ seconds; - $32$ seconds. [4] Assume that the skydiver's parachute failed to open. - Write down the terminal downward speed of the skydiver. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Solving the equation $V(0) = 0$ for $K$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  60 - \dfrac{K}{0+1} &= 0 \hspace{3.6em} \\[6pt]
  60 - K &= 0 \\  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.3em} \answer{K = 60} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we draw the graphs of $y = 60 - \dfrac{60}{t+1}$, for $t \geq 0$,
and $y = 12 + \dfrac{46}{t-28}$, for $t > 28$, on the grid below, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2df6984d-0273-4410-8b2b-ac32d48ec20c/images/3273e4d6-3871-4a0c-a24a-35721999c286/f1e6feb2dcd8269a36b82b80c11b2c1941011f79.svg)


- The piecewise function $V$ must be continuous at $T$.
Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.1em} 60 - \dfrac{60}{T+1} &= 12 + \dfrac{46}{T-28} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.15em} \answer{T = 29 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[6pt]
  $$

  Note that the value of $T$ is the
$x$-coordinate of the point A$(29,58)$ from part (b).
- 
  - Evaluating $V(t)$ for $t = 10$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{9em} V(10) &= 60 - \dfrac{60}{10+1} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $t = 10 < T = 29$}] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 54.5 \text{ m sec$^{-1}$}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $V(t)$ for $t = 32$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{9.4em} V(32) &= 12 + \dfrac{46}{32-28} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $t = 32 > T = 29$}] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 23.5 \text{ m sec$^{-1}$}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- $\answer{60 \text{ m sec\(^{-1}\)}}$

list.title: Question 90
list.content: An archer shoots an arrow at a circular target in front of her. The trajectory of the arrow is perpendicular to the circular target which is $x$ metres away. The height, in metres, of the arrows above the ground is found by the formula: $$ h = 0.015x+1.55 $$ - Find the height the arrow reaches when the target is $70$ meters away. [1] The centre of the target is at a height of $2.45\hspace{0.15em}$m above the ground. Hitting the inner circle of radius $12\,$cm scores $10$ points. The next circle has a radius of $22\,$cm and scores $8$ points. The final circle has a radius of $32\,$cm and scores $6$ points. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5808a386-ece2-424c-90ce-4d566c437d9c/images/7482106f-495f-482d-afe1-a3d0c43f39f3/q1126.png) - Find the score obtained by the shot. [2] The second shot is influenced by air resistance and the equation describing the height is now given by $$ h_2 = -0.001x^2 + 0.0791x + 1.55 $$ - Find the score obtained by the second shot. [2] - Calculate the maximum height reached by $h_2$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- By evaluating the formula at $x=70$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h &= 0.015(70)+1.55 \\[9pt]
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{= 2.6 \text{ m}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- The height above the centre of the target is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  d &= 2.6-2.45 \\[8pt]
  &= 15\text{ cm} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The arrow is within the second circle of radius $22\,$cm.
  The arrow scores $\answer{8}$.

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$


$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- Evaluating $h_2$ at $x=70$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h_2 &= -0.001(70)^2 + 0.0791(70)) + 1.55 \\[8pt]
  &= 2.187...
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence, the distance to the centre of the target is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  d_2 &= |2.187...-2.45| \\[8pt]
  &= 0.263...\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
  &= 26\hspace{0.15em}\text{cm}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The arrow is within the third circle of radius $32\,$cm.
  The arrow scores $\tcbhighmath{6}$

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$


$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = h_2(x)$, for $x \geq 0$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5808a386-ece2-424c-90ce-4d566c437d9c/images/1e39b79f-8205-4009-b8c4-b21d0dde44af/a1126.png)


  Hence the maximum height is $\answer{3.11 \text{ m}}$

  $$
  \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$

list.title: Question 91
list.content: A set of BMX jumping ramps have been constructed at a local cycle park, as shown in the following diagram. It is designed for riders to take off from the first ramp, represented by $f(x)$, and land on the second ramp, represented by $g(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6e6fba44-ae40-4292-a287-5720870a3e3e/images/72e41c7b-2eb3-46ea-a3bd-57ec52baf40b/1197a.JPG) $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ The first ramp starts at the origin and ends at point $A$, and has equation $f(x)=\dfrac{1}{3} x^2 \text{ for } 0\leq x \leq 3$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ The second ramp starts at point $C$ and ends at point $E$, and has equation $g(x)=\dfrac{1}{3} x^2-8x+48 \text{ for } 9\leq x \leq 12$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ $p(x)$ represents the path a rider would take in the air between the ramps between point $A$ and point $C$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ $q(x)$ represents a safety net that hangs between point $A$ and point $C$, and has equation $q(x)=\dfrac{1}{9} x^2-\dfrac{4}{3} x+6 \text{ for } 3\leq x \leq 9$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ Point $A$ has coordinates (3,3) and point $C$ has coordinates (9,3). It is given that all units and measurements are in metres. The path of a rider at point $A$ is the tangent to $f(x)$ at that point. - - Determine the gradient of $f(x)$ at point $A$. - Hence, determine the equation of the path of a rider at point $A$. Give your answer in the form $y=mx+c$.[4] The line $BC$ represents a support beam and is a normal to $g(x)$ at point $C$. - - Determine the gradient of $g(x)$ at point $C$. - Hence, determine the equation of the line representing the support beam $BC$.[6] $p(x)$ is a parabola with a maximum at (6,6). - Determine the equation of $p(x)$.[2] A safety regulation at the cycle park is that a BMX rider using the jumping ramps should never be more than 5 metres above the safety net while in the air. - Determine whether the model predicts that this safety regulation will be upheld. [4]

list.title: Question 92
list.content: A loaf pan is made in the shape of a cylinder. The pan has a diameter of $24$ cm and a height of $5$ cm. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aaafe79-56c4-4a37-b409-43676a3d5eed/images/855b65c5-7644-44f9-a953-a91912965eb3/a347288bee589088e6dce052611dad40b73c72e7.svg) - Calculate the volume of this pan. [3] Gloria prepares enough bread dough to exactly fill the pan. The dough was in the shape of a sphere. - Find the radius of the sphere in cm, correct to one decimal place. [4] The bread was cooked in a hot oven. Once taken out of the oven, the bread was left in the kitchen. The temperature, $T$, of the bread, in degrees Celsius, $\text{\textdegree{C}}$, can be modelled by the function $$ T(t) = a\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0, $$ where $a$ is a constant and $t$ is the time, in minutes, since the bread was taken out of the oven. When the bread was taken out of the oven its temperature was $205$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Find the value of $a$. [2] - Find the temperature that the bread will be $10$ minutes after it is taken out of the oven. [2] The bread can be eaten once its temperature drops to $35$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Calculate, to the nearest minute, the time since the bread was taken out of the oven until it can be eaten. [3] - In the context of this model, state what the value of $21$ represents. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Using the volume of a cylinder formula with $r = 12$ and $h = 5$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.05em} V_{\text{pan}} &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  &= \pi(12)^2(5) \\[6pt]
  &= 720\pi \qref{(1)}  \\[6pt]
  &=2261.9...\\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 2260 \text{ cm}^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the volume of a sphere formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} V_{\text{dough}} &= V_{\text{pan}} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3 &= 720\pi \hspace{3em} [\text{from  $(1)$}] \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $r$, we obtain

  $$
  \hspace{12.9em} \answer{r \approx 8.1 \text{ cm}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(0) = 205$ for $a$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\times(1.51)^0 + 21 &= 205 \hspace{5.65em} \\[6pt]
  a + 21 &= 205 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{a = 184}
  $$

- Evaluating $T(t)$ for $t=10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} T(10) &= 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{10}{3}} + 21 \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 67.6 \text{\hspace{0.15em}\textdegree{C}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(t) = 35$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.6em} 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21 &= 35 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 18.8 \hspace{3.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.8em} \answer{t \approx 19 \text{ minutes}}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{\(21\) is the room  temperature of the kitchen}}$

list.title: Question 93
list.content: A factory produces bars in the shape of a cuboid, with a fixed height of $30$ cm and varying base. The area, $A$, of each bar base is described by the function $$ \begin{aligned} A(x) &= x(40 - x), \hspace{0.5em} 5 \leq x \leq 35,\end{aligned} $$ where $x$ is the length of the bar base in centimetres. - Bar P has a length of $10$ cm. Find the volume of P. [2] - Bar Q has the same volume as bar P, however has a different length. Find the length of Q. [2] - Find the value of $x$ that makes the bar's volume a maximum, and state this maximum volume. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The volume of a bar with base length $x$ cm
is given by the function

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.95em} V(x) &= A(x)\times h \\[7pt]
  &= x(40-x)(30) \\[6pt]
  &= 1200x - 30x^2 \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, evaluating $V(x)$ for
$x = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.85em} V(10) &= 1200(10) - 30(10)^2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 9000 \text{ cm}^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $V(x) = 9000$ for $x \neq 10$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1200x - 30x^2 &= 9000 \hspace{6.7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.85em} \answer{x = 30 \text{ cm}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = V(x)$, for $5 \leq x \leq 35$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a4b969d0-4df7-4184-8874-c1e566eb036b/images/590e9d59-33f3-47b2-8b53-31174f419f04/862b3de66152091d457aa4678f6ddd98efb4d6c4.svg)


  Hence the maximum volume is
$\answer{12\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ cm}^3}$
and it occurs when
$\answer{x = 20 \text{ cm}}$

list.title: Question 94
list.content: In a water filtration plant, the containers of water are filled and then filtered, all by an automated system. The volume of water in a container, $W(t)$, in litres, after $t$ seconds of the filling commencing can be modelled by the function $$ W(t) = V(1-e^{\frac{-t}{k}}), $$ where $V$ is the maximum volume of the water container and $k$ is a positive constant used to alter the rate at which water is filling the containers. The value of $k$ is currently set at 25. - Find how long it takes, $t$, for a container to fill up to $50\%$ of its maximum volume. [2] - If one of the containers has a maximum volume of 20 litres, find the volume of water in this container after $22$ seconds. [2] The engineers of the plant want to alter the value of $k$ so that it takes $20$ seconds to fill each container up to $95\%$ of their maximum volumes. - Find the value of $k$ required. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Since the container is $50\%$ of its maximum volume,
$W=\dfrac{V}{2}$. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{V}{2}&=V(1-e^{\frac{-t}{25}})\\[6pt]
  \dfrac{1}{2}&=1-e^{\frac{-t}{25}}\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\answer{t\approx17.3 \text{ seconds}} \qquad \qquad \qquad [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting $V=20$ and $t=22$ into $W(t)$ function, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  W(t) &= V(1-e^{\frac{-t}{25}})\\[6pt]
  W(22)  &=20(1-e^{\frac{-22}{25}})\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{\approx11.7 \text{ litres}} \qquad \qquad \qquad [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since the containers are filled to $95\%$ of their maximum volume,
$W=0.95V$. Hence,

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.95V&=V(1-e^{\frac{-20}{k}})\\[6pt]
  0.95&=1-e^{\frac{-20}{k}}\\[6pt]
  e^{\frac{-20}{k}}&=0.05\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\answer{k\approx 6.68} \qquad \qquad \qquad [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 95
list.content: The Burj Khalifa, located in Dubai, is the tallest building in the world. It has a height of $830 \text{ m}$ and has a square base that covers a floor area of $556 \text{ m} \times 556 \text{ m}$. A tourism shop located near the building sells souvenirs of the tower, which sit inside glass pyramids, as illustrated by the diagram below. The souvenir tower is an accurate scale replica of the actual tower. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/490aa73b-d0b9-484e-9cf9-6362beb9193f/75dbfe1df45464ae26235a84b47e84fedd3f43ea.svg) The scaled model of Burj Khalifa has a base area of $20 \text{ cm} \times 20 \text{ cm}$. The height and base area dimensions of the glass pyramid are 10% larger than the model. - - Find the height of the souvenir tower, in cm, correct to the nearest mm. - Find the volume of the glass pyramid, rounding your answer correct to the nearest cubic centimetre. [5] The shop owner aims to maximise profits from selling the souvenirs. The more the owner orders from the manufacturer, the cheaper the souvenirs are to buy. However, if too many are ordered, profits may decrease due to surplus stock unsold. The number of souvenirs ordered from previous years and the resulting profits are shown in the following table. QuantityProfit($)$5000$$35\,000$$10\,000$$95\,500$$13\,000$$116\,500$ The shop owner decides to fit a cubic model of the form $$ P(x) = ax^3+bx^2+cx+d $$ to model the profit, $P$, for $x$ thousand souvenirs ordered. - Explain why $d=0$.[1] - Construct three linear equations to solve for $a$, $b$ and $c$, and hence write down the completed function $P(x)$. [5] - Find $P'(x)$.[2] - Find, to the nearest hundred souvenirs, the optimal number of souvenirs the owner should buy to maximise profit, and the resulting profit from this number. [4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The height $(h_m)$ of the model can be calculated by

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    h_m&= \text{height of Burj Khalifa} \times \text{scale factor}\\[6pt]
    &= 83000 \times \dfrac{20}{55600}\hspace{4.1em} [\text{all values in cm}] \\[6pt]
    &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx 29.9 \text{ cm} }\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Let $x$ be the side length of the base and $h$ be the height of
the glass pyramid. Since the dimensions of glass pyramid are
$10\%$ larger than the model, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x&= 20+20(0.1)\hspace{2cm} \\[6pt]
    &= 22 \text{ cm}\\[6pt]
    h&= 29.9+29.9(0.1)\\[6pt]
    &\approx 32.9 \text{ cm}\end{aligned}
    $$


  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/19611668-b3b5-4172-ace2-b6f0010e0b75/c16aa6b415e3ff65a129bf040b3ec43c108d55ec.svg)


  The volume $(V)$ of the glass pyramid can therefore be calculated by

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V&= \dfrac{1}{3}\times x^2 \times h \\[6pt]
  &=\dfrac{1}{3}\times (22)^2 \times(32.9)\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx 5308 \text{ cm}^3 }\end{aligned}
  $$

- If zero souvenirs are ordered (i.e. $x=0$), there won't be any
souvenirs to sell. Hence, the profit, $P$, will also be zero.

  $$
  \answer{P(0)=0, \,\text{ hence } \, d=0 }
  $$

- Since $x$ is in thousands, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(5)&=5^3a+5^2b+5c=35\, 000\qref{(1)}\\[6pt]
  P(10) &= 10^3a+10^2b+10c = 95\, 500\qref{(2)}\\[6pt]
  P(13) &= 13^3a+13^2b+13c = 116\, 500 \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using
G.D.C. to solve the equations $(1)$, $(2)$ and $(3)$, we get

  $$
  a=-\dfrac{2295}{26},\, b=\dfrac{47685}{26}, \text{ and } c=\dfrac{475}{13}
  $$

  Hence

  $$
  \hspace{0.3em}\answer{P(x) =-\dfrac{2295}{26}x^3+\dfrac{47685}{26}x^2+\dfrac{475}{13}x}
  $$

- Differentiating $P(x)$ with respect to $x$, we get

  $$
  \hspace{0.3em}\answer{P'(x) =-\dfrac{6885}{26}x^2+\dfrac{47685}{13}x+\dfrac{475}{13}}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $P(x)$, the maximum profit occurs at point
A.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/01769894-ccf2-4567-9e25-00dfe1fa2901/5541c9fa3d0d1b43403859281edadfc0d340eef4.svg)


  Using G.D.C. to find the coordinates of A, we get

  $$
  x=13.9, \text{ and } P(x)\approx 118\,000
  $$

  Hence,
  The maximum profit will occur when the owner buys
$\hspace{0.4em}\answer{13\,900}\hspace{0.4em}$ souvenirs.
The resulting profit will be approximately
$\hspace{0.35em}\answer{118\,000.}$

list.title: Question 96
list.content: The temperature, $T$, in degrees Celsius, in Istanbul during a particular winter day is modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} T &= a\sin\hspace{0.1em}(b\hspace{0.1em}(t-c))+d, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \end{aligned} $$ where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{R}$ and $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. The graph of $T$ versus $t$ is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fb0e5137-6e45-4694-89d8-210a316e08af/images/0d3b5230-b966-4d6e-bcd2-b7caf84d141a/6960bc2052fe8ed1bdd6d4f86c2a3bd840872a33.svg) The lowest temperature was recorded at $3$:$30$ am and the highest $\text{temperature}$ was recorded at $3$:$30$ pm. - Write down the value of: - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Find the smallest possible value of $c$, given $c > 0$. [2] The temperature, $T$, in degrees Celsius, in Istanbul during a particular summer day is modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} T &= 5\sin\hspace{0.1em}(0.262\hspace{0.1em}(t-8))+25, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Find the time, in hours and minutes, when the temperature: - reaches its maximum; - first drops below $24$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. [5] - The temperature is below $24$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$ for $h$ hours and $m$ minutes. Find the value of $h$ and the value of $m$.[2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    a &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} - T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{10 - 2}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} + T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{10 + 2}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 6}\end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $T$ is $24$ hours.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= \dfrac{2\pi}{24} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.262}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The max temperature occurs at $3$:$30$ pm ($t = 15.5$) and the mean
temperature occurs $6$ hours earlier.
  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.75em} t_{\text{max}} &= t_{\text{mean}} + 6 \\[6pt]
  15.5 &= c + 6 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{c = 9.5} \hspace{0.5em}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $T$ versus $t$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fb0e5137-6e45-4694-89d8-210a316e08af/images/2c85c575-3b76-42dc-84dd-5dda2f5b1cfd/22498aef2f9240c0f54bbcd77edc60575ac3345f.svg)


  
  - If we write $0.995$ hour in whole minutes, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1em} 0.995(60) &= 59.7 \\[6pt]
    &\approx 60 \text{ minutes}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the temperature
reaches maximum at
$\answer{\text{\(2\):\(00\) pm}}$
  - If we write $0.759$ hour in whole minutes, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1em} 0.759(60) &= 45.54 \\[6pt]
    &\approx 46 \text{ minutes}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the temperature
first drops below $24$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$ at
$\answer{\text{\(8\):\(46\) pm}}$

- Using the $x$-coordinates of B and C, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  24 - (20.759-7.231) &= 10.472 \text{ hours} \hspace{1.2em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we write $0.472$ hour in whole minutes, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.3em} 0.472(60) &= 28.32 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 28 \text{ minutes}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{h = 10}$
and  $\answer{m = 28}$

list.title: Question 97
list.content: A right cylinder has height $h$ mm and diameter $x$ mm. The volume of this cylinder is equal to $45$ mm$^3$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/efc9fbc4-0075-415f-b8c9-1a1def8352df/9aebb1d3e12c9fb1c552ed279ae0c28d1ca125c3.svg) The total surface area, $A$, of the cylinder can be expressed as $A = \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{k}{x}$. - Find the value of $k$. [4] - Find the value of $x$ that makes the total surface area a minimum. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Using the volume of a right cylinder formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  45 &= \pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2\hspace{-0.2em}h \\[3pt]
  45 &= \dfrac{\pi x^2h}{4} \\[6pt]
  h &= \dfrac{180}{\pi x^2} \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the total surface area is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} A(x) &= [\text{top \& bottom area}] + [\text{curved surface area}] \\[16pt]
  &=  2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh \\[9pt]
  &= 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2 + 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{180}{\pi x^2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{180}{x}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{k = 180}$
- If we sketch the graph of $y = A(x)$, for $x > 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/70443638-b03e-4b02-9371-621e475b9a63/10ad2caa42e46f8e9db41f9ae6642694c0b81ac1.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{x \approx 3.86 \text{  mm}}$
makes the total surface area a minimum.

list.title: Question 98
list.content: The distance travelled, $d$, in meters, of a freely falling object is proportional to the square of the time of the fall, $t$, in seconds. A football dropped from the top of a school building falls a distance of $19.6\text{ m}$ in the first $2$ seconds. - Show that $d(t)=4.9t^2$. [2] - Sketch the curve of $d$ for $t>0$, clearly showing the point $(2,19.6)$. [2] The distance covered, $s$, in meters, by a quad-copter drone undertaking a vertical landing can be modelled by $s(t) = 8t$, where $t$ is the time in seconds after the landing commences. The football is dropped at the same time as the drone commences a landing from the same height of the school building. The football covers more distance than the drone when $t>p$. - Find the value of $p$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Since $d$ varies proportionally with the square of $t$, we can state

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d&=kt^2 \quad \text{[where k is a constant]}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have
$d=19.6 \text{ m}$ when $t=2\text{ s}$. We can use these to find
$k$:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  19.6 &= k(2)^{2}\hspace{3.8cm}\\[6pt]
  k&=4.9\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, we have shown

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{-7em}\answer{d=4.9t^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using GDC, we can plot the curve of $d(t)=4.9t^2$ for $t>0$, as
shown
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/08b312a2-f2be-4c99-a017-56011a6e21b2/images/14d89890-1629-4583-8dca-99e74de71942/523fcfa1c1e8c9a28b03f2d2499ceebab285f5d8.svg)


- The curves of $d(t)=4.9t^2$ and $s(t)=8t$ are plotted on the graph
below
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/08b312a2-f2be-4c99-a017-56011a6e21b2/images/ff8238cb-8231-4138-b80c-2159b3626395/f8c3444e7186ece84caeb418dfee107029e62cc6.svg)


  From the graph, $d(t) > s(t)$ when $t>1.63$. Hence,
$\answer{p=1.63}$

list.title: Question 99
list.content: The security personnel at the entry of a rural campground activate a siren to alert campers when a wild animal is spotted nearby. The sound intensity, $I$, of the siren varies inversely with the square of the distance from the siren, $d$. When initially testing the siren, the security personnel found that at a distance of $3$ metres from the siren, the sound intensity is $5$ watts per square metre $(\text{Wm}^{-2})$. - Show that $I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}$. [2] - Sketch the curve of $I$ for $d>0$, labelling the point $(3,5)$. [2] The campers can only hear the siren if the sound intensity at their location is greater than $1.2\times10^{-5} \text{Wm}^{-2}$. - Find the minimum distance, in kilometers, from the siren where the campers can no longer hear the siren. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Since $I$ varies inversely with the square of $d$, we can state

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I&=\dfrac{k}{d^2} \quad \text{[where k is a constant]}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have $I=5 \text{ Wm}^{-2}$ when $d=3\text{ m}$. We can use these to find $k$:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 &= \dfrac{k}{3^2}\hspace{3.8cm}\\[6pt]
  k&=45\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, we have shown

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \tcbhighmath{I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using GDC, we can plot the curve of $I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}$ for $d>0$, as shown
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/151224cf-2f80-4345-b68e-a612caa31abb/images/612a624d-0502-474e-802f-6124a743e115/AI875.PNG)


- Campers can only hear the siren when $I>1.2\times 10^{-5}$. Therefore

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I &> 1.2\times 10^{-5} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{45}{d^2} &> 1.2\times 10^{-5}\\[6pt]
  \dfrac{45}{1.2\times 10^{-5}}&>d^2\\[6pt]
  d &< \sqrt{\dfrac{45}{1.2\times 10^{-5}}}\\[6pt]
  d &< 1936.49\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, the minimum distance from the siren is $\answer{1.94 \text{ km}}$

list.title: Question 100
list.content: The mean depth, $D$, in metres, of a mountain lake fluctuates in a yearly cycle and can be modelled by the function $$ D(t) = a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(k t) + b, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in months, since the beginning of an autumn season. The mean depth of the lake on month $1$ is $33.2$ m and on month $5$ is $22.8$ m. - Find the value of $k$, in degrees. [2] - Set up a pair of equations and find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. Give your answers correct to the nearest integer. [3] - Hence find the mean depth of the lake on month $8$. [2] - Draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ on the grid below, for one full year, indicating clearly the minimum and maximum points. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/650b6656-5f6c-4fd2-980c-ceab4bbe6228/22e9fb4574cbc4ff36d7eb0e402d77e50876a875.svg) - Determine the total amount of time in one year that the mean depth is expected to be lower than 26 metres. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The period of $D$ is $12$ months.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k &= \dfrac{\ang{360}}{12} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \ang{30}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(1) &= 33.2 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 1) + b &= 33.2 \\[6pt]
  0.866a + b &= 33.2 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(5) &= 22.8 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 5) + b &= 22.8 \\[6pt]
  -0.866a + b &= 22.8 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the
system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.8em} \answer{a \approx 6} \hspace{1em}\text{ and }\hspace{1em} \answer{b \approx 28} \hspace{3.8em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $D(t)$ for $t = 8$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(8) &= 6\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times8) + 28 \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 25 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max mean depths of the lake during the year are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.2em} D_{\text{min}} &= 6(-1)+28 \\[6pt]
  &= 22 \text{ m} \hspace{1em} [\text{when } t = (0.5)12 = 9] \\[15pt]
  D_{\text{max}} &= 6(+1)+28 \\[6pt]
  &= 34 \text{ m} \hspace{1em} [\text{when } t = (0)12 = 0\hspace{0.25em}\&\hspace{0.25em}t = (1)12 = 12]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ on the grid below, for
$0 \leq t \leq 12$, indicating the points A$(0,34)$, B$(12,34)$ and
C$(6,22)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/2b12daf7-2a64-4082-be83-d94cf2bb913d/73e28209b510fb17f449ac18e686993a5d03e3ef.svg)


- Adding the graph of $y=26$ to our solution from part (d), we can find the points of intersection:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/afc9ddca-9147-42e2-83ce-681f27150723/ai177a.PNG)



  $$
  \begin{align*}
  8.351-3.649 &= 4.702
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The mean depth of the lake is lower than $26$ metres for approximately $\answer{\text{$4.70$ months.}}$

list.title: Question 101
list.content: A new class of antibiotics is studied in the medical research center. Antibiotics are applied to a pure culture of bacteria. The number of bacteria, $N$, present in the culture $t$ hours after the start of the experiment are recorded. The results are shown in the table below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c408642-a9dc-4bbb-957a-5d6a5fe9857e/images/7ce99e72-9c18-4516-b553-7fa9196ca477/e1fb081fc41a9cc621eeb3b2ff28f126bbc93514.svg) - Complete the third row of the table above. [2] - Draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, scaling the axes if needed. [3] - State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your scatter diagram from part (b). [1] A researcher in the center claims that the number of bacteria, $N$, left in the culture $\text{after}$ applying antibiotics can be modelled by an exponential function of the form $N(t) = a\times b^t$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive constants. - Explain why the researcher is correct. [4] - Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Calculating the values of $\log N$, we get

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c408642-a9dc-4bbb-957a-5d6a5fe9857e/images/520e95cb-de01-4462-a729-e7b911bbcb85/61b4f3ec9ac851d948d8978ac81720c3afe52589.svg)



- If we draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c408642-a9dc-4bbb-957a-5d6a5fe9857e/images/fefd2280-20f5-4296-828e-ec96dc4feb80/e884512675852ac6da9bd0f7c67f1081c0ab4d85.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- Using the properties of exponents, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.2em} \log N(t) &= mt + c \hspace{3em} [\text{by parts (b) and (c)}] \\[8pt]
  10^{mt+c} &= N(t) \hspace{3em} [\text{by definition of log}] \\[8pt]
  (10^{mt})(10^c) &= N(t) \\[8pt]
  N(t) &= (10^c)(10^{m})^t\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we obtain
$N(t) = a\times b^t$ for $a = 10^c$ and $b = 10^m$.
- The equation of the regression line of $\log N$ on $t$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11em} \log N(t) &= -0.13765t + 4.84028 \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} a &= 10^{4.84028} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 69\hspace{0.15em}200}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.9em} b &= 10^{-0.13765} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.728}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 102
list.content: The amount of water, $A$, in thousands of litres, available in a water tank located on a farm fluctuates in a yearly cycle and can be modelled by the function $$ A(t) = a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(k t) + b, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in weeks, since the start of the year. The amount of water available in the tank on week $6$ is $24$ thousand litres and on week $31$ is $9.2$ thousand litres. - Find the value of $k$, in degrees, assuming there are $52$ whole weeks in a year.[2] - Set up a pair of equations to find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. Give your answers correct to the nearest integer. [3] - Hence find the amount of water available in the tank in week $42$. [2] - Draw the graph of $y = A(t)$ on the grid below, for one full year, indicating clearly the minimum and maximum points. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f9ea1ac-4ddd-4bad-86a6-cabf74ce33e5/images/e6db81cc-44d6-4dec-bb02-b8db7bb46b78/a35842049aa426b4bf5aefe8b287a6da9db53a2d.svg) - Determine the total number of weeks that the amount of water in the tank is at least $24\,000$ litres. Give your answer to the nearest week. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The period of $A$ is $52$ weeks.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k &= \dfrac{\ang{360}}{52} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx \ang{6.92}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  A(6) &= 24 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{6.92}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 6) + b &= 24 \\[6pt]
  0.663a + b &= 24 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  A(31) &= 9.2 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{6.92}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 31) + b &= 9.2 \\[6pt]
  -0.567a + b &= 9.2 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the
system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.5em} \answer{a \approx 12} \hspace{1em}\text{ and }\hspace{1em} \answer{b \approx 16} \hspace{3.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $A(t)$ for $t = 42$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} A(42) &= 12\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{6.92}\hspace{-0.15em}\times42) + 16 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4.77 \text{ thousand litres}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The min and max values of the sine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max amounts of water in the tank available during
the year are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.3em} A_{\text{min}} &= 12(-1)+16 \\[6pt]
  &= 4 \text{ thousand litres} \hspace{2.5em} [\text{when } t = (0.75)52 = 39] \\[15pt]
  A_{\text{max}} &= 12(+1)+16 \\[6pt]
  &= 28 \text{ thousand litres} \hspace{2em} [\text{when } t = (0.25)52 = 13]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we draw the graph of $y = A(t)$ on the grid below, for
$0 \leq t \leq 52$, indicating the points P$(13,28)$ and Q$(39,4)$,
we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f9ea1ac-4ddd-4bad-86a6-cabf74ce33e5/images/b8498a75-a823-45e9-98f9-710beed4d209/8814e237c9bc7b3142ac40e7f50be90d39e62a05.svg)


- Adding the graph of $y=24$ to our solution from part (d), we can find the points of intersection:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f9ea1ac-4ddd-4bad-86a6-cabf74ce33e5/images/ebef324b-3baf-41cb-98f1-619d4c70d32a/ai176a.PNG)


  The amount of water in the tank is at least $24\,000$ litres for $\answer{\text{$14$ weeks}}$ (to the nearest week).

list.title: Question 103
list.content: A particular species of microbes is studied in the laboratory. Microbes are grown under controlled conditions in pure culture. The number of microbes, $N$, present in the culture $t$ hours after the start of the experiment are recorded. The results are shown in the table below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/e0c72216-8582-4a43-b865-6568739b5e03/05f74794f9493b7052849a256cb95a218dff9b51.svg) - Complete the third row of the table above. [2] - Draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, scaling the axes if needed. [3] - State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your scatter diagram from part (b). [1] A scientist in the laboratory claims that the number of microbes, $N$, grown in the laboratory during the experiment can be modelled by an exponential function of the form $N(t) = a\times b^t$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive constants. - Explain why the scientist is correct. [4] - Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Calculating the values of $\log N$, we get

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/04df3b88-45a9-4949-aa9e-88b0f0bf335c/6cf620ba27d00fb0d7be6bd8c31f6e9e22c0c9ce.svg)



- If we draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/18131649-4993-445a-99d1-5cf1380f097e/73d2d06aa23839e33065bdf471930d83ad8030b6.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- Using the properties of exponents, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.2em} \log N(t) &= mt + c \hspace{3em} [\text{by parts (b) and (c)}] \\[8pt]
  10^{mt+c} &= N(t) \hspace{3em} [\text{by definition of log}] \\[8pt]
  (10^{mt})(10^c) &= N(t) \\[8pt]
  N(t) &= (10^c)(10^{m})^t\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we obtain
$N(t) = a\times b^t$ for $a = 10^c$ and $b = 10^m$.
- The equation of the regression line of $\log N$ on $t$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11em} \log N(t) &= 0.14521t + 1.69035 \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} a &= 10^{1.69035} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 49.0}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.3em} b &= 10^{0.14521} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1.40}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 104
list.content: Alexandros monitors the temperature during a particular day in Athens. The table below shows some of his findings. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/000aea6e-7d28-4e46-a9b8-b0aa808a7144/images/84e35a2c-c6d5-4386-b2a4-aeae6e3c1d12/063047b1151b8885e1ce8bf5005a5b210fdafca9.svg) Based on his observations, Alexandros concludes that the temperature, $T$, in $\text{\textdegree{C}}$, during the day can be modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} T &= a\sin\hspace{0.1em}(b\hspace{0.1em}(t-c)) + d, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Write down the value of: - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Find the smallest possible value of $c$, given $c > 0$. [2] - Find the time, in hours and minutes, when the temperature first reaches $35\text{\textdegree{C}}$ during the day. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.4em} a &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} - T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{39.2 - 25.4}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 6.9}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.4em} d &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} + T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{39.2 + 25.4}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 32.3}\end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $T$ is $24$ hours.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= \dfrac{2\pi}{24} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.262}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The max temperature occurs at $4$:$12$ pm ($t = 16.2$) and the mean
temperature occurs $6$ hours earlier.
  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.75em} t_{\text{max}} &= t_{\text{mean}} + 6 \\[6pt]
  16.2 &= c + 6 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{c = 10.2}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of
$T = 6.9\sin\hspace{0.1em}(2.62\hspace{0.1em}(t-10.2)) + 32.3$
versus $t$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/000aea6e-7d28-4e46-a9b8-b0aa808a7144/images/b598813c-3dbe-453d-be50-5744baac0524/be78b702b9ccf256126ee3383eee8affe77f9461.svg)


  If we write $0.735$ hour in whole minutes, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.735(60) &= 44.1 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 44 \text{ minutes} \hspace{0.65em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
temperature first reaches $35$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$ during the
day at
$\answer{\text{\(11\):\(44\) am}}$

list.title: Question 105
list.content: The sound intensity level (SIL), $L$, in decibels (dB), of the sound intensity, $I$, in watts per square meter, is given by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} L &= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I}{I_0}\right),\end{aligned} $$ where $I_0$ is the reference sound intensity. - Two sounds have intensities $I_1$ and $I_2$ with $I_1 < I_2$. Show that the difference in SIL between the two sounds is $\triangle L = 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right)$. [3] - A train rumble has the SIL of $82$ dB and a dishwasher noise has the SIL of $52$ dB. Find the number of times the train rumble is more intense than the dishwasher noise. [3] Jack is attending a rock concert where the SIL of the music reaches $110$ dB. During the concert, Jack's mom calls him to find out if he is safe and everything is going well. The SIL of his cell phone ring is $70$% of the SIL of the rock music. - The perceived loudness of a sound doubles for every $10$ dB increase in SIL. - Write down the SIL of Jack's cell phone ring. - Jack perceives the rock music $k$ times as loud as his cell phone ringing. Find the value of $k$, giving your answer correct to $3$ significant figures. - Hence, decide whether Jack's mom will reach him during the concert if Jack carries his cell phone in the pocket and turned vibrating alert off. [5]
list.markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.3em} \triangle L  &= L_2 - L_1 \\[6pt]
  &= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_0}\right) - 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_1}{I_0}\right) \\[6pt]
  &= 10\left[\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_0}\right) - \log\left(\dfrac{I_1}{I_0}\right)\right] \\[6pt]
  &= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_0} \div \dfrac{I_1}{I_0}\right) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we let $I_1$ and $I_2$ be the intensities of the dishwasher noise
and the train rumble, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \triangle L &= 82 - 52 \\[10pt]
  \hspace{1.3em} 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right) &= 30 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[5pt]
  \log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right) &= 3 \\[5pt]
  10^3 &= \dfrac{I_2}{I_1} \\[10pt]
  I_2 &= 1000I_1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the train rumble is
$\answer{1000 \text{ times}}$
more intense than the dishwasher noise.
- 
  - The SIL of Jack's cell phone ring is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    L &= 110(0.70) \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 77 \text{ dB}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{\triangle L}{10} &= \dfrac{110 - 77}{10} \hspace{2.9em} \\[6pt]
    &= 3.3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    k &= 2^{3.3} \\[8pt]
    &\answer{\approx 9.85} \hspace{3.9em}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Jack's mom will not reach him during the concert b/c the rock music is too loud to hear cell phone ringing

list.title: Question 106
list.content: Peter wants to reach a rock, located $5$ km away from his current position, using the strategy outlined below. Every hour Peter approaches the rock by a fixed percent of the remaining distance to the rock. The distance, $D$, in kilometres, Peter has travelled from his original position, can be modelled by the exponential function $$ \begin{aligned} D(t) = a + b\big(k^{-t}\big), \hspace{0.5em} t\geq 0, \end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the time, in hours, since Peter started moving. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/f49c99b3-6084-4cce-b203-48eef7cf3293/819ba2cfeb3383629fe25649fde3301bcf8c76d4.svg) - Explain why $a= 5$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] After one hour, the distance from Peter to the rock is $3.75$ km. - Find the value of $k$. [2] - Find the distance between Peter and the rock after $4$ hours. [2] Peter can be heard when shouting from $200$ metres away. - Calculate the time it takes until someone standing on the rock can hear Peter shouting. Round your answer correct to the nearest hour. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/749982c8-e46c-4506-bf93-4534155f5e67/284ba0b0f6db44c91e038d4ec5486789b5846da8.svg)


  On the other hand, we know Peter will not travel more than
$5$ km.
  Hence we must have $a = 5$.
- Solving the equation $D(0) = 0$ for $t$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 + b\big(k^{0}\big) &= 0 \hspace{1.6em} \\[6pt]
  5 + b &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.8em} \answer{b = -5}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(1) = 5 - 3.75 = 1.25$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 - 5\big(k^{-1}\big) &= 1.25 \hspace{2.35em} \\[10pt]
  5 - \dfrac{5}{k} &= \dfrac{5}{4} \\[6pt]
  1 - \dfrac{1}{k} &= \dfrac{1}{4} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{3}{4} &= \dfrac{1}{k} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{k = \dfrac{4}{3}}
  $$

- Evaluating $D(t)$ for $t = 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} D(4) &= 5 - 5\hspace{-0.15em}\left(\dfrac{4}{3}\right)^{-4} \\[6pt]
  &\approx 3.42\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, the distance between Peter and
the rock after $4$ hours is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5  - D(4) &= 5 - 3.42 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1.58 \text{ km}} \hspace{1.4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(t) = 5 - 0.2 = 4.80$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.8em} 5 - 5\big(k^{-t}\big) &= 4.80 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 11.2 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it takes
$\answer{11 \text{ hours}}$
until someone on the rock can hear Peter shouting.

list.title: Question 107
list.content:
Adam is examining two quantities, $x$ and $y$, he plots some of their values on a log-log graph. The points all lie on a straight line.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/88dbe517-954b-4161-bbb7-0130a8c81f46/images/52fbfca2-5892-40a0-b406-ecc7df68469b/q1148.png)


He notices the line goes through the points $(x_1, 78.944)$ and $(287.545, y_2)$.
He also notices that $y_2$ is equal to $3x_1$.
The gradient on the line shown on the graph is $-0.24720$.
Find a relationship between $y$ and $x$ that does not include any logarithmic functions. Give any parameter values to $4$ significant figures.
list.markScheme:
As this we see a straight line when plotting a log-log graph the relationship between $x$ and $y$ must be of the form $y=ax^n$.

$$
\tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}
$$

$\textcolor{white}{gap}$
We can take the log of both sides and simplify

$$
\begin{align*}
    \log{y}&=\log{ax^n}\\
    \log{y}&=\log{a} + \log{x^n}\\
    \log{y}&=\log{a} + n\log{x}
\end{align*}
$$

By comparing the rearranged equation above to $y=mx+c$ we can see that the gradient ($m$) of the log-log graph will be equal to $n$.
We have that $m = -0.24720$, hence we can write $y=ax^{-0.24720}$.

$$
\tag*{\textbf{(A1)}}
$$

$\textcolor{white}{gap}$
Now we must find the value of $a$.
Substituting in the coordinates of the two points we were given, $(x_1 , 78.944)$ and $(287.545 , 3x_1)$, we have

$$
\begin{align*}
    78.944 = a(x_1)^{-0.24720} \hspace{2em} &\text{and} \hspace{2em} 3x_1 = a(287.545)^{-0.24720} \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}
\end{align*}
$$

Rearranging these equations to make $a$ the subject, we have

$$
\begin{align*}
     a = 78.944(x_1)^{0.24720} \hspace{2em} &\text{and} \hspace{2em} a = 3\left(287.545^{0.24720}\right)x_1 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}
\end{align*}
$$

Using the G.D.C., we can sketch these two graphs of $a$ against $x_1$ and find the point of intersection:

$$
\tag*{\textbf{(M2)}}
$$

$\textcolor{white}{gap}$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/88dbe517-954b-4161-bbb7-0130a8c81f46/images/856609d7-1ab0-446b-984c-8faf5de7b363/a1148.png)


This tells us that $a=145.9$ and $x_1=12.00$.
Hence $\answer{y=145.9x^{-0.2472}}$.

$$
\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
$$

$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

list.title: Question 108
list.content: Grace is planning on making a 3D printed model of a well-known hill in her local area. She knows that the hill itself is approximately $400$ metres wide and $200$ metres high. A cross-section of the hill is shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cfe367d7-cb6b-4d07-9047-93411b82d289/images/2db6ab35-c4bc-460a-be02-e3598d5f4f04/1198a.JPG) Grace plans to model the cross-section of the hill using a piecewise function, $f(x)$, consisting of a first function, $f_1(x)$ for $0 \leq x \leq 200$ and a second function, $f_2(x)$ for $200 < x \leq 400$. For the first section, Grace decides on a logistic function of the form $$ \begin{align*} f_1(x) &= \dfrac{202}{1+Ce^{-kx}} \text{ , where } C,k>0 \end{align*} $$ A point approximately halfway up the hill has coordinates $(100,120.684)$. Using these coordinates, Grace makes the equation $$ \begin{align*} C &= 0.6738\,e^{100k} \end{align*} $$ The summit of the hill has approximate coordinates $(200,201.087)$. - Using these coordinates, find a second expression for $C$ in terms of $k$. [3] - Hence find the value of $C$ and the value of $k$. [3] For the second section, Grace creates a function $f_2(x)$, which she finds by performing the following two transformations on $f_1(x)$ in order: $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ A reflection in the $y$-axis; $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ A translation of $400$ units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis. - Write a complete expression for $f_2(x)$. [3] - Hence write $f(x)$ as a piecewise function. [1] Grace wants her 3D printed model to be of scale $1:2\,000$. This is equivalent to applying both a vertical stretch and horizontal stretch of scale factor $\frac{1}{2\,000}$ to her piecewise function. - Write a piecewise function for Grace's model, $g(x)$. [4] To determine the volume of plastic she requires for her 3D printed model, Grace finds the volume generated when $g(x)$ is rotated $\bm{180^{\circ}}$ about the $x$-axis. - Determine the volume of plastic Grace will require.[3]

list.title: Question 109
list.content: Farmer Jimmy bought $50$ goats and brought them to his farm. He determined that $10$ of these new goats have a viral disease. The total number of goats on Jimmy's farm is now $600$. The spread of the viral disease on Jimmy's farm is modelled by the logistic function $$ \begin{aligned} S(d) &= \dfrac{M}{1 + Ce^{-kd}}\hspace{0.05em},\end{aligned} $$ where $S(d)$ is the number of infected goats after $d$ epidemic days. - - Write down the value of $M$. - Find the value of $C$. [3] - Given that quarter of the goats are infected after $12$ days, find the value of $k$, giving your answer correct to $4$ significant figures.[2] - Find the number of days it takes for $90$% of the goats to get infected. [2] - Draw the graph of $y= S(d)$ on the axes below, indicating clearly the point of inflexion and any asymptotes. [5] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f49e72e7-6584-4138-8054-6fe5008cecf7/images/5238f531-f132-4a58-becb-d0b7ebce7daa/af42c884652048f15edb5d1b0dcdec977e9e56fd.svg)
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{M = 600}$
  - Solving the equation $S(0) = 10$ for $C$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{600}{1 + Ce^{-k(0)}} &= 10 \hspace{8.9em} \\[6pt]
    \dfrac{600}{1 + C} &= 10 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{6.3em} \answer{C = 59} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
    $$


- Solving the equation $S(12) = 600(0.25)$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{600}{1 + 59e^{-k(12)}} &= 150 \hspace{6.8em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.6em} \answer{k \approx 0.2482} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $S(d) = 600(0.9)$ for $d$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{600}{1 + 59e^{-0.2482d}} &= 540 \hspace{7.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.9em} \answer{d \approx 25.3 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- The $d$-coordinate of the point of inflexion of the graph of
$y = S(d)$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.1em} d &= \dfrac{1}{k}\times\ln\hspace{-0.1em}\left(\dfrac{M-S_0}{S_0}\right) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{0.2482}\times\ln\hspace{-0.1em}\left(\dfrac{600-10}{10}\right) \\[12pt]
  &\approx 16.4\end{aligned}
  $$

  The $y$-coordinate of the point of
inflexion of the graph of $y = S(d)$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= \dfrac{M}{2} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{600}{2} \\[11pt]
  &= 300 \hspace{3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we draw the graph of
$y= S(d)$ on the axes below, indicating clearly the point
P$(16.4,300)$ and the horizontal asymptote $y = 600$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f49e72e7-6584-4138-8054-6fe5008cecf7/images/be5970ef-68da-418b-9d72-254b0894ca0e/f13c820f0c9b4084407257c9965d8746335e62cc.svg)

list.title: Question 110
list.content: John operates a small clothing factory that manufactures jeans. John observes that the weekly total production cost, $C$, in Australian dollars (AUD), and the number of jeans produced per week, $N$, can be related by the equation $$ C = aN^b + K, $$ where $a,b$ and $K$ are positive constants. John estimates that the weekly total fixed cost of $\text{operating}$ the $\text{factory}$ is $7500$ AUD. - Write down the value of $K$. [1] After analysing the financial accounting records of a particular month, John finds the data given below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/879f95c0-4366-46af-9667-a1ccca321eee/fbdd8eb79d6d3959b803e0d70b8e5774db6d8585.svg) - Draw a scatter diagram of $\ln(C-K)$ versus $\ln N$, scaling and shifting the axes if needed. [4] - State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your scatter diagram from part (b). [1] - Write down the equation of the regression line of $\ln(C-K)$ on $\ln N$. [2] - Hence find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4] John wants to increase the production rate of jeans up to $1000$ pairs per week. - Using John's equation, estimate the weekly total cost of producing $1000$ jeans.[2] - State whether it is valid to use John's equation to estimate the weekly total cost of producing $1000$ jeans. Give a reason for your answer. [1] - - Describe how the data must be entered into your G.D.C. to determine John's equation using power regression method. - Hence verify your answers to part (e). [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{7500}$
- Calculating the values of $\ln N$ and $\ln(C-7500)$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/f919f4c4-0ab8-4082-b3a5-15f4da729b49/42ab6379e4ab4c55ae6f463560051439ba03d313.svg)


  Hence, if we draw a scatter diagram of $\ln(C-7500)$ versus $\ln N$,
we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/a09fc063-5ba5-4f42-b9b2-3fd0bef02a7d/59f5b36505be1f8ae52acc1dbbb0c27f31c1e5d3.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- $\answer{\ln(C-7500) = 0.806\ln N + 5.14}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Using the properties of logarithms, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \ln(C-7500) &= 0.806\ln N + 5.14 \\[6pt]
  \ln(C-7500) &= \ln N^{0.806} + \ln e^{5.14} \\[6pt]
  \ln(C-7500) &= \ln (171N^{0.806}) \hspace{3em} [e^{5.14} \approx 171] \\[6pt]
  C - 7500 &= 171N^{0.806} \\[6pt]
  C &= 171N^{0.806} + 7500\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = 171}$
and  $\answer{b = 0.806}$
- Evaluating $C$ when $N = 1000$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} C &= 171(1000)^{0.806} + 7500 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 52\hspace{0.15em}300 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{Not valid, \(N = 1000\) is not within the range of the given data}}$
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    C &= aN^b + 7500 \hspace{1.1em} \\[6pt]
    C - 7500 &= aN^b \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{the values of \(C - 7500\) versus \(N\)}}$
must entered into G.D.C.
    to determine John's equation using power regression method.
  - Calculating the values of $C-7500$, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/1f7e6fa7-9fd5-4060-8aaa-a14e7aab59d1/99598c9925b5a9cd2c17f6f04553a8bf43f297df.svg)


    Entering the data above into G.D.C. as described in part (h)
(i), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.3em} C - 7500 &= 177N^{0.800} \hspace{2em} [\text{by power regression}]\\[6pt]
    C &= 177N^{0.800} + 7500\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we find
$\answer{a = 177}$
and
$\answer{b = 0.800}$
as expected.

list.title: Question 111
list.content: Sandra operates a pizzeria that has $24$ hours delivery service. Sandra thinks that the daily total production cost, $C$, in euros (EUR), and the number of pizzas made per day, $N$, can be related by the equation $$ C = aN^b + K, $$ where $a,b$ and $K$ are positive constants. Sandra estimates that the daily total fixed cost of $\text{operating}$ the $\text{pizzeria}$ is $1000$ EUR. - Write down the value of $K$. [1] After analysing the bookkeeping records of a particular working week, Sandra finds the data given below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb0acab8-5dc0-4da0-b2ae-e9c280e0b35f/images/4e23917d-54ed-4b09-9333-7c0c9887c487/7bb8aad63a8010d3b18aca0ec2b8af0e9af7f108.svg) - Draw a scatter diagram of $\log_2(C-K)$ versus $\log_2 N$, scaling and shifting the axes if needed. [4] - State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your scatter diagram from part (b). [1] - Write down the equation of the regression line of $\log_2(C-K)$ on $\log_2 N$. [2] - Hence find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4] Sandra wants to increase the selling rate of pizzas up to $800$ items per day. - Using Sandra's equation, estimate the daily total cost of producing $800$ $\text{pizzas}$.[2] - State whether it is valid to use Sandra's equation to estimate the daily total cost of producing $800$ pizzas. Give a reason for your answer. [1] - - Describe how the data must be entered into your G.D.C. to determine Sandra's equation using power regression method. - Hence verify your answers to part (e). [4]
list.markScheme:
